verses.textEn: But when they hand you over, do not choose to think about how or what to speak. For what to speak shall be given to you in that hour.
verses.textLa: Cum autem tradent vos, nolite cogitare quomodo, aut quid loquamini: dabitur enim vobis in illa hora, quid loquamini.

verses.textEn: For it is not you who will be speaking, but the Spirit of your Father, who will speak in you.
verses.textLa: Non enim vos estis qui loquimini, sed Spiritus Patris vestri, qui loquitur in vobis.

verses.textEn: And brother will hand over brother to death, and father will hand over son. And children will rise up against parents and bring about their deaths.
verses.textLa: Tradet autem frater fratrem in mortem, et pater filium: et insurgent filii in parentes, et morte eos afficient:

verses.textEn: And you will be hated by all for the sake of my name. But whoever will have persevered, even to the end, the same shall be saved.
verses.textLa: et eritis odio omnibus propter nomen meum: qui autem perseveraverit usque in finem, hic salvus erit.

verses.textEn: Now when they persecute you in one city, flee into another. Amen I say to you, you will not have exhausted all the cities of Israel, before the Son of man returns.
verses.textLa: Cum autem persequentur vos in civitate ista, fugite in aliam. Amen dico vobis, non consummabitis civitates Israel, donec veniat Filius hominis.

verses.textEn: The disciple is not above the teacher, nor is the servant above his master.
verses.textLa: Non est discipulus super magistrum, nec servus super dominum suum.

verses.textEn: It is sufficient for the disciple that he be like his teacher, and the servant, like his master. If they have called the Father of the family, ‘Beelzebub,’ how much more those of his household?
verses.textLa: Sufficit discipulo, ut sit sicut magister eius: et servo, sicut dominus eius. Si Patrem familias Beelzebub vocaverunt: quanto magis domesticos eius?

verses.textEn: Therefore, do not fear them. For nothing is covered that shall not be revealed, nor hidden that shall not be known.
verses.textLa: Ne ergo timueritis eos: Nihil enim est opertum, quod non revelabitur: et occultum, quod non scietur.

verses.textEn: What I tell you in darkness, speak in the light. And what you hear whispered in the ear, preach above the rooftops.
verses.textLa: Quod dico vobis in tenebris, dicite in lumine: et quod in aure auditis, prædicate super tecta.

verses.textEn: And do not be afraid of those who kill the body, but are not able to kill the soul. But instead fear him who is able to destroy both soul and body in Hell.
verses.textLa: Et nolite timere eos, qui occidunt corpus, animam autem non possunt occidere: sed potius timete eum, qui potest et animam, et corpus perdere in Gehennam.

verses.textEn: Are not two sparrows sold for one small coin? And yet not one of them will fall to the ground without your Father.
verses.textLa: Nonne duo passeres asse væneunt? et unus ex illis non cadet super terram sine Patre vestro?

verses.textEn: For even the hairs of your head have all been numbered.
verses.textLa: Vestri autem capilli capitis omnes numerati sunt.

verses.textEn: Therefore, do not be afraid. You are worth more than many sparrows.
verses.textLa: Nolite ergo timere: multis passeribus meliores estis vos.

verses.textEn: Therefore, everyone who acknowledges me before men, I also will acknowledge before my Father, who is in heaven.
verses.textLa: Omnis ergo, qui confitebitur me coram hominibus, confitebor et ego eum coram Patre meo, qui in cælis est:

verses.textEn: But whoever will have denied me before men, I also will deny before my Father, who is in heaven.
verses.textLa: qui autem negaverit me coram hominibus, negabo et ego eum coram Patre meo, qui in cælis est.

verses.textEn: Do not think that I came to send peace upon the earth. I came, not to send peace, but the sword.
verses.textLa: Nolite arbitrari quia pacem venerim mittere in terram: non veni pacem mittere, sed gladium.

verses.textEn: For I came to divide a man against his father, and a daughter against her mother, and a daughter-in-law against her mother-in-law.
verses.textLa: Veni enim separare hominem adversus patrem suum, et filiam adversus matrem suam, et nurum adversus socrum suam:

verses.textEn: And the enemies of a man will be those of his own household.
verses.textLa: et inimici hominis, domestici eius.

verses.textEn: Whoever loves father or mother more than me is not worthy of me. And whoever loves son or daughter above me is not worthy of me.
verses.textLa: Qui amat patrem, aut matrem plus quam me, non est me dignus. Et qui amat filium, aut filiam super me, non est me dignus.

verses.textEn: And whoever does not take up his cross and follow me is not worthy of me.
verses.textLa: Et qui non accipit crucem suam, et sequitur me, non est me dignus.

verses.textEn: Whoever finds his life, will lose it. And whoever will have lost his life because of me, shall find it.
verses.textLa: Qui invenit animam suam, perdet illam: et qui perdiderit animan suam propter me, inveniet eam.

verses.textEn: Whoever receives you, receives me. And whoever receives me, receives him who sent me.
verses.textLa: Qui recipit vos, me recipit: et qui me recipit, recipit eum, qui me misit.

verses.textEn: Whoever receives a prophet, in the name of a prophet, shall receive the reward of a prophet. And whoever receives the just in the name of the just shall receive the reward of the just.
verses.textLa: Qui recipit prophetam in nomine prophetæ, mercedem prophetæ accipiet: et qui recipit iustum in nomine iusti, mercedem iusti accipiet.

verses.textEn: And whoever shall give, even to one of the least of these, a cup of cold water to drink, solely in the name of a disciple: Amen I say to you, he shall not lose his reward.”
verses.textLa: Et quicumque potum dederit uni ex minimis istis calicem aquæ frigidæ tantum in nomine discipuli: amen dico vobis, non perdet mercedem suam.

verses.textEn: And it happened that, when Jesus had completed instructing his twelve disciples, he went away from there in order to teach and to preach in their cities.
verses.textLa: Et factum est, cum consummasset Iesus, præcipiens duodecim discipulis suis, transiit inde ut doceret, et prædicaret in civitatibus eorum.

verses.textEn: Now when John had heard, in prison, about the works of Christ, sending two of his disciples, he said to him,
verses.textLa: Ioannes autem cum audisset in vinculis opera Christi, mittens duos de discipulis suis,

verses.textEn: “Are you he who is to come, or should we expect another?”
verses.textLa: ait illi: Tu es, qui venturus es, an alium expectamus?

verses.textEn: And Jesus, responding, said to them: “Go and report to John what you have heard and seen.
verses.textLa: Et respondens Iesus ait illis: Euntes renunciate Ioanni quæ audistis, et vidistis.

verses.textEn: The blind see, the lame walk, the lepers are cleansed, the deaf hear, the dead rise again, the poor are evangelized.
verses.textLa: Cæci vident, claudi ambulant, leprosi mundantur, surdi audiunt, mortui resurgunt, pauperes evangelizantur:

verses.textEn: And blessed is he who has found no offense in me.”
verses.textLa: et beatus est, qui non fuerit scandalizatus in me.

verses.textEn: Then, after they departed, Jesus began to speak to the crowds about John: “What did you go out to the desert to see? A reed shaken by the wind?
verses.textLa: Illis autem abeuntibus, cœpit Iesus dicere ad turbas de Ioanne: Quid existis in desertum videre? arundinem vento agitatem?

verses.textEn: So what did you go out to see? A man in soft garments? Behold, those who are clothed in soft garments are in the houses of kings.
verses.textLa: Sed quid existis videre? hominem mollibus vestitum? Ecce qui mollibus vestiuntur, in domibus regum sunt.

verses.textEn: Then what did you go out to see? A prophet? Yes, I tell you, and more than a prophet.
verses.textLa: Sed quid existis videre? prophetam? Etiam dico vobis, et plus quam prophetam.

verses.textEn: For this is he, of whom it is written: ‘Behold, I send my Angel before your face, who shall prepare your way before you.’
verses.textLa: Hic est enim, de quo scriptum est: Ecce ego mitto Angelum meum ante faciem tuam, qui præparabit viam tuam ante te.
verses.notes: Even though John was not literally an Angel, Jesus used the word for angels because John was angelic.

verses.textEn: Amen I say to you, among those born of women, there has arisen no one greater than John the Baptist. Yet the least in the kingdom of heaven is greater than he.
verses.textLa: Amen dico vobis, non surrexit inter natos mulierum maior Ioanne Baptista: qui autem minor est in regno cælorum, maior est illo.

verses.textEn: But from the days of John the Baptist, even until now, the kingdom of heaven has endured violence, and the violent carry it away.
verses.textLa: A diebus autem Ioannis Baptistæ usque nunc, regnum cælorum vim patitur, et violenti rapiunt illud.

verses.textEn: For all the prophets and the law prophesied, even until John.
verses.textLa: Omnes enim prophetæ, et lex usque ad Ioannem prophetaverunt:

verses.textEn: And if you are willing to accept it, he is the Elijah, who is to come.
verses.textLa: et si vultis recipere, ipse est Elias, qui venturus est.

verses.textEn: Whoever has ears to hear, let him hear.
verses.textLa: Qui habet aures audiendi, audiat.

verses.textEn: But to what shall I compare this generation? It is like children sitting in the marketplace,
verses.textLa: Cui autem similem æstimabo generationem istam? Similis est pueris sedentibus in foro: qui clamantes coæqualibus

verses.textEn: who, calling out to their companions, say: ‘We played music for you, and you did not dance. We lamented, and you did not mourn.’
verses.textLa: dicunt: Cecinimus vobis, et non saltastis: lamentavimus, et non planxistis.

verses.textEn: For John came neither eating nor drinking; and they say, ‘He has a demon.’
verses.textLa: Venit enim Ioannes neque manducans, neque bibens, et dicunt: Dæmonium habet.

verses.textEn: The Son of man came eating and drinking; and they say, ‘Behold, a man who eats voraciously and who drinks wine, a friend of tax collectors and sinners.’ But wisdom is justified by her sons.”
verses.textLa: Venit Filius hominis manducans, et bibens, et dicunt: Ecce homo vorax, et potator vini, publicanorum, et peccatorum amicus. Et iustificata est sapientia a filiis suis.

verses.textEn: Then he began to rebuke the cities in which many of his miracles were accomplished, for they still had not repented.
verses.textLa: Tunc cœpit exprobrare civitatibus, in quibus factæ sunt plurimæ virtutes eius, quia non egissent pœnitentiam.

verses.textEn: “Woe to you, Chorazin! Woe to you, Bethsaida! For if the miracles that were done in you had been done in Tyre and Sidon, they would have repented long ago in haircloth and ashes.
verses.textLa: Væ tibi Corozain, væ tibi Bethsaida: quia, si in Tyro, et Sidone factæ essent virtutes quæ factæ sunt in vobis, olim in cilicio, et cinere pœnitentiam egissent.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, I say to you, Tyre and Sidon shall be forgiven more than you, on the day of judgment.
verses.textLa: Verumtamen dico vobis: Tyro, et Sidoni remissius erit in die iudicii, quam vobis.

verses.textEn: And you, Capernaum, would you be exalted all the way to heaven? You shall descend all the way to Hell. For if the miracles that were done in you had been done in Sodom, perhaps it would have remained, even to this day.
verses.textLa: Et tu Capharnaum, numquid usque in cælum exaltaberis? usque in infernum descendes. Quia, si in Sodomis factæ fuissent virtutes, quæ factæ sunt in te, forte mansissent usque in hanc diem.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, I say to you, that the land of Sodom shall be forgiven more than you, on the day of judgment.”
verses.textLa: Verumtamen dico vobis, quia terræ Sodomorum remissius erit in die iudicii, quam tibi.

verses.textEn: At that time, Jesus responded and said: “I acknowledge you, Father, Lord of Heaven and earth, because you have hidden these things from the wise and the prudent, and have revealed them to little ones.
verses.textLa: In illo tempore respondens Iesus dixit: Confiteor tibi, Pater, Domine cæli et terræ, quia abscondisti hæc a sapientibus, et prudentibus, et revelasti ea parvulis.

verses.textEn: Yes, Father, for this was pleasing before you.
verses.textLa: Ita Pater: quoniam sic fuit placitum ante te.

verses.textEn: All things have been delivered to me by my Father. And no one knows the Son except the Father, nor does anyone know the Father except the Son, and those to whom the Son is willing to reveal him.
verses.textLa: Omnia mihi tradita sunt a Patre meo. Et nemo novit Filium, nisi Pater: neque Patrem quis novit, nisi Filius, et cui voluerit Filius revelare.

verses.textEn: Come to me, all you who labor and have been burdened, and I will refresh you.
verses.textLa: Venite ad me omnes, qui laboratis, et onerati estis, et ego reficiam vos.

verses.textEn: Take my yoke upon you, and learn from me, for I am meek and humble of heart; and you shall find rest for your souls.
verses.textLa: Tollite iugum meum super vos, et discite a me, quia mitis sum, et humilis corde: et invenietis requiem animabus vestris.

verses.textEn: For my yoke is sweet and my burden is light.”
verses.textLa: Iugum enim meum suave est, et onus meum leve.

verses.textEn: At that time, Jesus went out through the ripe grain on the Sabbath. And his disciples, being hungry, began to separate the grain and to eat.
verses.textLa: In illo tempore abiit Iesus per sata Sabbato: discipuli autem eius esurientes cœperunt vellere spicas, et manducare.

verses.textEn: Then the Pharisees, seeing this, said to him, “Behold, your disciples are doing what is not lawful to do on the Sabbaths.”
verses.textLa: Pharisæi autem videntes, dixerunt ei: Ecce discipuli tui faciunt quod non licet facere Sabbatis.

verses.textEn: But he said to them: “Have you not read what David did, when he was hungry, and those who were with him:
verses.textLa: At ille dixit eis: Non legistis quid fecerit David, quando esuriit, et qui cum eo erant:

verses.textEn: how he entered the house of God and ate the bread of the Presence, which was not lawful for him to eat, nor for those who were with him, but only for the priests?
verses.textLa: quomodo intravit in domum Dei, et panes propositionis comedit, quos non licebat ei edere, neque his, qui cum eo erant, nisi solis sacerdotibus?

verses.textEn: Or have you not read in the law, that on the Sabbaths the priests in the temple violate the Sabbath, and they are without guilt?
verses.textLa: Aut non legistis in lege quia sabbatis sacerdotes in templo sabbatum violant, et sine crimine sunt?

verses.textEn: But I say to you, that something greater than the temple is here.
verses.textLa: Dico autem vobis, quia templo maior est hic.

verses.textEn: And if you knew what this means, ‘I desire mercy, and not sacrifice,’ you would never have condemned the innocent.
verses.textLa: Si autem sciretis, quid est: Misericordiam volo, et non sacrificium: numquam condemnassetis innocentes:

verses.textEn: For the Son of man is Lord even of the Sabbath.”
verses.textLa: Dominus enim est Filius hominis etiam Sabbati.

verses.textEn: And when he had passed from there, he went into their synagogues.
verses.textLa: Et cum inde transisset, venit in synagogam eorum.

verses.textEn: And behold, there was a man who had a withered hand, and they questioned him, so that they might accuse him, saying, “Is it lawful to cure on the Sabbaths?”
verses.textLa: Et ecce homo manum habens aridam, et interrogabant eum, dicentes: Si licet Sabbatis curare? ut accusarent eum.

verses.textEn: But he said to them: “Who is there among you, having even one sheep, if it will have fallen into a pit on the Sabbath, would not take hold of it and lift it up?
verses.textLa: Ipse autem dixit illis: Quis erit ex vobis homo, qui habeat ovem unam, et si ceciderit hæc Sabbatis in foveam, nonne tenebit, et levabit eam?

verses.textEn: How much better is a man than a sheep? And so, it is lawful to do good on the Sabbaths.”
verses.textLa: Quanto magis melior est homo ove? Itaque licet Sabbatis benefacere.

verses.textEn: Then he said to the man, “Extend your hand.” And he extended it, and it was restored to health, just like the other one.
verses.textLa: Tunc ait homini: Extende manum tuam. Et extendit, et restituta est sanitati sicut altera.

verses.textEn: Then the Pharisees, departing, took council against him, as to how they might destroy him.
verses.textLa: Exeuntes autem Pharisæi, consilium faciebant adversus eum, quomodo perderent eum.

verses.textEn: But Jesus, knowing this, withdrew from there. And many followed him, and he cured them all.
verses.textLa: Iesus autem sciens recessit inde: et secuti sunt eum multi, et curavit eos omnes:

verses.textEn: And he instructed them, lest they make him known.
verses.textLa: et præcepit eis ne manifestum eum facerent.

verses.textEn: Then what was spoken through the prophet Isaiah was fulfilled, saying:
verses.textLa: Ut adimpleretur quod dictum est per Isaiam prophetam, dicentem:

verses.textEn: “Behold, my servant whom I have chosen, my beloved in whom my soul is well pleased. I will place my Spirit over him, and he shall announce judgment to the nations.
verses.textLa: Ecce puer meus, quem elegi, dilectus meus, in quo bene complacuit animæ meæ. Ponam Spiritum meum super eum, et iudicium gentibus nunciabit.

verses.textEn: He shall not contend, nor cry out, neither shall anyone hear his voice in the streets.
verses.textLa: Non contendet, neque clamabit, neque audiet aliquis in plateis vocem eius:

verses.textEn: He shall not crush the bruised reed, and he shall not extinguish the smoking wick, until he sends forth judgment unto victory.
verses.textLa: arundinem quassatam non confringet, et linum fumigans non extinguet, donec eiiciat ad victoriam iudicium:

verses.textEn: And the Gentiles shall hope in his name.”
verses.textLa: et in nomine eius Gentes sperabunt.

verses.textEn: Then one who had a demon, who was blind and mute, was brought to him. And he cured him, so that he spoke and saw.
verses.textLa: Tunc oblatus est ei dæmonium habens, cæcus, et mutus, et curavit eum ita ut loqueretur, et videret.

verses.textEn: And all the crowds were stupefied, and they said, “Could this be the son of David?”
verses.textLa: Et stupebant omnes turbæ, et dicebant: Numquid hic est filius David?

verses.textEn: But the Pharisees, hearing it, said, “This man does not cast out demons, except by Beelzebub, the prince of the demons.”
verses.textLa: Pharisæi autem audientes, dixerunt: Hic non eiicit dæmones nisi in Beelzebub principe dæmoniorum.

verses.textEn: But Jesus, knowing their thoughts, said to them: “Every kingdom divided against itself will become desolate. And every city or house divided against itself will not stand.
verses.textLa: Iesus autem sciens cogitationes eorum, dixit eis: Omne regnum divisum contra se, desolabitur: et omnis civitas, vel domus divisa contra se, non stabit.

verses.textEn: So if Satan casts out Satan, then he is divided against himself. How then will his kingdom stand?
verses.textLa: Et si Satanas Satanam eiicit, adversus se divisus est: quomodo ergo stabit regnum eius?

verses.textEn: And if I cast out demons by Beelzebub, by whom do your own sons cast them out? Therefore, they shall be your judges.
verses.textLa: Et si ego in Beelzebub eiicio dæmones, filii vestri in quo eiiciunt? Ideo ipsi iudices vestri erunt.

verses.textEn: But if I cast out demons by the Spirit of God, then the kingdom of God has arrived among you.
verses.textLa: Si autem ego in Spiritu Dei eiicio dæmones, igitur pervenit in vos regnum Dei.

verses.textEn: Or how can anyone enter into the house of a strong man, and plunder his belongings, unless he first restrains the strong man? And then he will plunder his house.
verses.textLa: Aut quomodo potest quisquam intrare in domum fortis, et vasa eius diripere, nisi prius alligaverit fortem? Et tunc domum illius diripiet.

verses.textEn: Whoever is not with me, is against me. And whoever does not gather with me, scatters.
verses.textLa: Qui non est mecum, contra me est: et qui non congregat mihi, spargit.

verses.textEn: For this reason, I say to you: Every sin and blasphemy shall be forgiven men, but blasphemy against the Spirit shall not be forgiven.
verses.textLa: Ideo dico vobis: Omne peccatum, et blasphemia remittetur hominibus, Spiritus autem blasphemia non remittetur.
verses.notes: Blasphemy against the Holy Spirit is nothing other than final impenitence.

verses.textEn: And anyone who will have spoken a word against the Son of man shall be forgiven. But whoever will have spoken against the Holy Spirit shall not be forgiven, neither in this age, nor in the future age.
verses.textLa: Et quicumque dixerit verbum contra Filium hominis, remittetur ei: qui autem dixerit contra Spiritum Sanctum, non remittetur ei neque in hoc sæculo, neque in futuro.

verses.textEn: Either make the tree good and its fruit good, or make the tree evil and its fruit evil. For certainly a tree is known by its fruit.
verses.textLa: Aut facite arborem bonam, et fructum eius bonum: aut facite arborem malam, et fructum eius malum: Si quidem ex fructu arbor agnoscitur.

verses.textEn: Progeny of vipers, how are you able to speak good things while you are evil? For out of the abundance of the heart, the mouth speaks.
verses.textLa: Progenies viperarum, quomodo potestis bona loqui, cum sitis mali? ex abundantia enim cordis os loquitur.

verses.textEn: A good man offers good things from a good storehouse. And an evil man offers evil things from an evil storehouse.
verses.textLa: Bonus homo de bono thesauro profert bona: et malus homo de malo thesauro profert mala.

verses.textEn: But I say to you, that for every idle word which men will have spoken, they shall render an account in the day of judgment.
verses.textLa: Dico autem vobis quoniam omne verbum otiosum, quod locuti fuerint homines, reddent rationem de eo in die iudicii.

verses.textEn: For by your words shall you be justified, and by your words shall you be condemned.”
verses.textLa: Ex verbis enim tuis iustificaberis, et ex verbis tuis condemnaberis.

verses.textEn: Then certain ones from the scribes and the Pharisees responded to him, saying, “Teacher, we want to see a sign from you.”
verses.textLa: Tunc responderunt ei quidam de Scribis et Pharisæis, dicentes: Magister, volumus a te signum videre.

verses.textEn: And answering, he said to them: “An evil and adulterous generation seeks a sign. But a sign will not be given to it, except the sign of the prophet Jonah.
verses.textLa: Qui respondens ait illis: Generatio mala, et adultera signum quærit: et signum non dabitur ei, nisi signum Ionæ prophetæ.

verses.textEn: For just as Jonah was in the belly of the whale for three days and three nights, so shall the Son of man be in the heart of the earth for three days and three nights.
verses.textLa: Sicut enim fuit Ionas in ventre ceti tribus diebus, et tribus noctibus; sic erit Filius hominis in corde terræ tribus diebus, et tribus noctibus.
verses.notes: The Jews counted any part of a day as a whole; so three days and three nights need not be 24 hours times 3. Also, Christ was taken prisoner on Thursday evening, and then confined in a subterranean prison overnight (first night in the heart of the earth). He died on Friday about the ninth hour, and was buried in a tomb before sunset (the first day). He then remained dead to the world for Friday night (the second night) and Saturday daytime (the second day) as well as Saturday night (the third night). He arose early on Sunday after first light (the third day). Therefore, His statement that He would be three days and three nights in the heart of the earth is true.

verses.textEn: The men of Nineveh shall arise in judgment with this generation, and they shall condemn it. For, at the preaching of Jonah, they repented. And behold, there is a greater than Jonah here.
verses.textLa: Viri Ninivitæ surgent in iudicio cum generatione ista, et condemnabunt eam: quia pœnitentiam egerunt in prædicatione Ionæ. Et ecce plus quam Ionas hic.

verses.textEn: The Queen of the South shall arise in judgment with this generation, and she shall condemn it. For she came from the ends of the earth to hear the wisdom of Solomon. And behold, there is a greater than Solomon here.
verses.textLa: Regina Austri surget in iudicio cum generatione ista, et condemnabit eam: quia venit a finibus terræ audire sapientiam Salomonis, et ecce plus quam Salomon hic.

verses.textEn: Now when an unclean spirit departs from a man, he walks through dry places, seeking rest, and he does not find it.
verses.textLa: Cum autem immundus spiritus exierit ab homine, ambulat per loca arida, quærens requiem, et non invenit.

verses.textEn: Then he says, ‘I will return to my house, from which I departed’. And arriving, he finds it vacant, swept clean, and decorated.
verses.textLa: Tunc dicit: Revertar in domum meam, unde exivi. Et veniens invenit eam vacantem, scopis mundatam, et ornatam.

verses.textEn: Then he goes and takes with him seven other spirits more wicked than himself, and they enter in and live there. And in the end, the man becomes worse than he was at first. So, too, shall it be with this most wicked generation.”
verses.textLa: Tunc vadit, et assumit septem alios spiritus secum nequiores se, et intrantes habitant ibi: et fiunt novissima hominis illius peiora prioribus. Sic erit et generationi huic pessimæ.

verses.textEn: While he was still speaking to the crowds, behold, his mother and his brothers were standing outside, seeking to speak with him.
verses.textLa: Adhuc eo loquente ad turbas, ecce mater eius, et fratres stabant foras, quærentes loqui ei.

verses.textEn: And someone said to him: “Behold, your mother and your brothers are standing outside, seeking you.”
verses.textLa: Dixit autem ei quidam: Ecce mater tua, et fratres tui foris stant quærentes te.

verses.textEn: But responding to the one speaking to him, he said, “Which one is my mother, and who are my brothers?”
verses.textLa: At ipse respondens dicenti sibi, ait: Quæ est mater mea, et qui sunt fratres mei?

verses.textEn: And extending his hand to his disciples, he said: “Behold: my mother and my brothers.
verses.textLa: Et extendens manum in discipulos suos, dixit: Ecce mater mea, et fratres mei.

verses.textEn: For anyone who does the will of my Father, who is in heaven, the same is my brother, and sister, and mother.”
verses.textLa: Quicumque enim fecerit voluntatem Patris mei, qui in cælis est: ipse meus frater, et soror, et mater est.

verses.textEn: In that day, Jesus, departing from the house, sat down beside the sea.
verses.textLa: In illo die exiens Iesus de domo, sedebat secus mare.
verses.notes: The phrase ‘in illo die’ could also be translated as ‘in that day,’ meaning in that general time, not necessarily on the same exact day.

verses.textEn: And such great crowds were gathered to him that he climbed into a boat and he sat down. And the entire multitude stood on the shore.
verses.textLa: Et congregatæ sunt ad eum turbæ multæ, ita ut naviculam ascendens sederet: et omnis turba stabat in littore,

verses.textEn: And he spoke many things to them in parables, saying: “Behold, a sower went out to sow seed.
verses.textLa: et locutus est eis multa in parabolis, dicens: Ecce exiit qui seminat, seminare.

verses.textEn: And while he was sowing, some fell beside the road, and the birds of the air came and ate it.
verses.textLa: Et dum seminat, quædam ceciderunt secus viam, et venerunt volucres cæli, et comederunt ea.

verses.textEn: Then others fell in a rocky place, where they did not have much soil. And they sprung up promptly, because they had no depth of soil.
verses.textLa: Alia autem ceciderunt in petrosa, ubi non habebant terram multam: et continuo exorta sunt, quia non habebant altitudinem terræ.

verses.textEn: But when the sun rose up, they were scorched, and because they had no roots, they withered.
verses.textLa: Sole autem orto æstuaverunt: et quia non habebant radicem, aruerunt.

verses.textEn: Still others fell among thorns, and the thorns increased and suffocated them.
verses.textLa: Alia autem ceciderunt in spinas: et creverunt spinæ, et suffocaverunt ea.

verses.textEn: Yet some others fell upon good soil, and they produced fruit: some one hundred fold, some sixty fold, some thirty fold.
verses.textLa: Alia autem ceciderunt in terram bonam: et dabant fructum aliud centesimum, aliud sexagesimum, aliud trigesimum.

verses.textEn: Whoever has ears to hear, let him hear.”
verses.textLa: Qui habet aures audiendi, audiat.

verses.textEn: And his disciples drew near to him and said, “Why do you speak to them in parables?”
verses.textLa: Et accedentes discipuli dixerunt ei: Quare in parabolis loqueris eis?

verses.textEn: Responding, he said to them: “Because it has been given to you to know the mysteries of the kingdom of heaven, but it has not been given to them.
verses.textLa: Qui respondens, ait illis: Quia vobis datum est nosse mysteria regni cælorum: illis autem non est datum.

verses.textEn: For whoever has, it shall be given to him, and he shall have in abundance. But whoever has not, even what he has shall be taken away from him.
verses.textLa: Qui enim habet, dabitur ei, et abundabit: qui autem non habet, et quod habet auferetur ab eo.

verses.textEn: For this reason, I speak to them in parables: because seeing, they do not see, and hearing they do not hear, nor do they understand.
verses.textLa: Ideo in parabolis loquor eis: quia videntes non vident, et audientes non audiunt, neque intelligunt.

verses.textEn: And so, in them is fulfilled the prophecy of Isaiah, who said, ‘Hearing, you shall hear, but not understand; and seeing, you shall see, but not perceive.
verses.textLa: Et adimpletur in eis prophetia Isaiæ dicentis: Auditu audietis, et non intelligetis: et videntes videbitis, et non videbitis:

verses.textEn: For the heart of this people has grown fat, and with their ears they hear heavily, and they have closed their eyes, lest at any time they might see with their eyes, and hear with their ears, and understand with their heart, and be converted, and then I would heal them.’
verses.textLa: Incrassatum est enim cor populi huius, et auribus graviter audierunt, et oculos suos clauserunt: ne quando videant oculis, et auribus audiant, et corde intelligant, et convertantur, et sanem eos.

verses.textEn: But blessed are your eyes, because they see, and your ears, because they hear.
verses.textLa: Vestri autem beati oculi quia vident, et aures vestræ quia audiunt.

verses.textEn: Amen I say to you, certainly, that many of the prophets and the just desired to see what you see, and yet they did not see it, and to hear what you hear, and yet they did not hear it.
verses.textLa: Amen quippe dico vobis, quia multi prophetæ, et iusti cupierunt videre quæ videtis, et non viderunt: et audire quæ auditis, et non audierunt.

verses.textEn: Listen, then, to the parable of the sower.
verses.textLa: Vos ergo audite parabolam seminantis.

verses.textEn: With anyone who hears the word of the kingdom and does not understand it, evil comes and carries away what was sown in his heart. This is he who received the seed by the side of the road.
verses.textLa: Omnis, qui audit verbum regni, et non intelligit, venit malus, et rapit quod seminatum est in corde eius: hic est qui secus viam seminatus est.

verses.textEn: Then whoever has received the seed upon a rocky place, this is one who hears the word and promptly accepts it with joy.
verses.textLa: Qui autem super petrosa seminatus est, hic est, qui verbum audit, et continuo cum gaudio accipit illud:

verses.textEn: But he has no root in himself, so it is only for a time; then, when tribulation and persecution occur because of the word, he promptly stumbles.
verses.textLa: non habet autem in se radicem, sed est temporalis. Facta autem tribulatione et persecutione propter verbum, continuo scandalizatur.

verses.textEn: And whoever has received the seed among thorns, this is he who hears the word, but the cares of this age and the falseness of riches suffocate the word, and he is effectively without fruit.
verses.textLa: Qui autem seminatus est in spinis, hic est, qui verbum audit, et solicitudo sæculi istius, et fallacia divitiarum suffocat verbum, et sine fructu efficitur.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, whoever has received the seed into good soil, this is he who hears the word, and understands it, and so he bears fruit, and he produces: some a hundred fold, and another sixty fold, and another thirty fold.”
verses.textLa: Qui vero in terram bonam seminatus est, hic est qui audit verbum, et intelligit, et fructum affert, et facit aliud quidem centesimum, aliud autem sexagesimum, aliud vero trigesimum.

verses.textEn: He proposed another parable to them, saying: “The kingdom of heaven is like a man who sowed good seed in his field.
verses.textLa: Aliam parabolam proposuit illis, dicens: Simile factum est regnum cælorum homini, qui seminavit bonum semen in agro suo.

verses.textEn: But while the men were sleeping, his enemy came and sowed weeds amid the wheat, and then went away.
verses.textLa: Cum autem dormirent homines, venit inimicus eius, et superseminavit zizania in medio tritici, et abiit.

verses.textEn: And when the plants had grown, and had produced fruit, then the weeds also appeared.
verses.textLa: Cum autem crevisset herba, et fructum fecisset, tunc apparuerunt et zizania.

verses.textEn: So the servants of the Father of the family, approaching, said to him: ‘Lord, did you not sow good seed in your field? Then how is it that it has weeds?’
verses.textLa: Accedentes autem servi Patris familias, dixerunt ei: Domine, nonne bonum semen seminasti in agro tuo? Unde ergo habet zizania?

verses.textEn: And he said to them, ‘A man who is an enemy has done this.’ So the servants said to him, ‘Is it your will that we should go and gather them up?’
verses.textLa: Et ait illis: Inimicus homo hoc fecit: Servi autem dixerunt ei, Vis, imus, et colligimus ea?

verses.textEn: And he said: ‘No, lest perhaps in gathering the weeds, you might also root out the wheat together with it.
verses.textLa: Et ait: Non: ne forte colligentes zizania, eradicetis simul cum eis et triticum.

verses.textEn: Permit both to grow until the harvest, and at the time of the harvest, I will say to the reapers: Gather first the weeds, and bind them into bundles to burn, but the wheat gather into my storehouse.’ ”
verses.textLa: Sinite utraque crescere usque ad messem, et in tempore messis dicam messoribus: Colligite primum zizania, et alligate ea in fasciculos ad comburendum, triticum autem congregate in horreum meum.

verses.textEn: He proposed another parable to them, saying: “The kingdom of heaven is like a grain of mustard seed, which a man took and sowed in his field.
verses.textLa: Aliam parabolam proposuit eis dicens: Simile est regnum cælorum grano sinapis, quod accipiens homo seminavit in agro suo:

verses.textEn: It is, indeed, the least of all seeds, but when it has grown, it is greater than all the plants, and it becomes a tree, so much so that the birds of the air come and dwell in its branches.”
verses.textLa: quod minimum quidem est omnibus seminibus: cum autem creverit, maius est omnibus oleribus, et fit arbor, ita ut volucres cæli veniant, et habitent in ramis eius.
verses.notes: This verse is not so much about the literal mustard seeds, as about the Church that is represented by it.

verses.textEn: He spoke another parable to them: “The kingdom of heaven is like leaven, which a woman took and hid in three measures of fine wheat flour, until it was entirely leavened.”
verses.textLa: Aliam parabolam locutus est eis. Simile est regnum cælorum fermento, quod acceptum mulier abscondit in farinæ satis tribus, donec fermentatum est totum.

verses.textEn: All these things Jesus spoke in parables to the crowds. And he did not speak to them apart from parables,
verses.textLa: Hæc omnia locutus est Iesus in parabolis ad turbas: et sine parabolis non loquebatur eis:

verses.textEn: in order to fulfill what was spoken through the prophet, saying: “I will open my mouth in parables. I will proclaim what has been hidden since the foundation of the world.”
verses.textLa: ut impleretur quod dictum erat per prophetam, dicentem: Aperiam in parabolis os meum, eructabo abscondita a constitutione mundi.

verses.textEn: Then, dismissing the crowds, he went into the house. And his disciples drew near to him, saying, “Explain to us the parable of the weeds in the field.”
verses.textLa: Tunc, dimissis turbis, venit in domum: et accesserunt ad eum discipuli eius, dicentes: Edissere nobis parabolam zizaniorum agri.

verses.textEn: Responding, he said to them: “He who sows the good seed is the Son of man.
verses.textLa: Qui respondens ait illis: Qui seminat bonum semen, est Filius hominis.

verses.textEn: Now the field is the world. And the good seeds are the sons of the kingdom. But the weeds are the sons of wickedness.
verses.textLa: Ager autem, est mundus. Bonum vero semen, hi sunt filii regnum. Zizania autem, filii sunt nequam.

verses.textEn: So the enemy who sowed them is the devil. And truly, the harvest is the consummation of the age; while the reapers are the Angels.
verses.textLa: Inimicus autem, qui seminavit ea, est diabolus. Messis vero, consummatio sæculi est. Messores autem, Angeli sunt.

verses.textEn: Therefore, just as weeds are gathered up and burned with fire, so shall it be at the consummation of the age.
verses.textLa: Sicut ergo colliguntur zizania, et igni comburuntur: sic erit in consummatione sæculi.

verses.textEn: The Son of man shall send out his Angels, and they shall gather from his kingdom all who lead astray and those who work iniquity.
verses.textLa: Mittet Filius hominis Angelos suos, et colligent de regno eius omnia scandala, et eos, qui faciunt iniquitatem:

verses.textEn: And he shall cast them into the furnace of fire, where there shall be weeping and gnashing of teeth.
verses.textLa: et mittent eos in caminum ignis. Ibi erit fletus, et stridor dentium.

verses.textEn: Then the just ones shall shine like the sun, in the kingdom of their Father. Whoever has ears to hear, let him hear.
verses.textLa: Tunc iusti fulgebunt sicut sol in regno Patris eorum. Qui habet aures audiendi, audiat.

verses.textEn: The kingdom of heaven is like a treasure hidden in a field. When a man finds it, he hides it, and, because of his joy, he goes and sells everything that he has, and he buys that field.
verses.textLa: Simile est regnum cælorum thesauro abscondito in agro: quem qui invenit homo, abscondit, et præ gaudio illius vadit, et vendit universa quæ habet, et emit agrum illum.

verses.textEn: Again, the kingdom of heaven is like a merchant seeking good pearls.
verses.textLa: Iterum simile est regnum cælorum homini negotiatori, quærenti bonas margaritas.

verses.textEn: Having found one pearl of great value, he went away and sold all that he had, and he bought it.
verses.textLa: Inventa autem una pretiosa margarita, abiit, et vendidit omnia quæ habuit, et emit eam.

verses.textEn: Again, the kingdom of heaven is like a net cast into the sea, which gathers together all kinds of fish.
verses.textLa: Iterum simile est regnum cælorum sagenæ missæ in mare, et ex omni genere piscium congreganti.

verses.textEn: When it has been filled, drawing it out and sitting beside the shore, they selected the good into vessels, but the bad they threw away.
verses.textLa: Quam, cum impleta esset, educentes, et secus littus sedentes, elegerunt bonis in vasa, malos autem foras miserunt.

verses.textEn: So shall it be at the consummation of the age. The Angels shall go forth and separate the bad from the midst of the just.
verses.textLa: Sic erit in consummatione sæculi: exibunt Angeli, et separabunt malos de medio iustorum,

verses.textEn: And they shall cast them into the furnace of fire, where there will be weeping and gnashing of teeth.
verses.textLa: et mittent eos in caminum ignis: ibi erit fletus, et stridor dentium.

verses.textEn: Have you understood all these things?” They say to him, “Yes.”
verses.textLa: Intellexistis hæc omnia? Dicunt ei: Etiam.

verses.textEn: He said to them, “Therefore, every scribe well-taught about the kingdom of heaven, is like a man, the father of a family, who offers from his storehouse both the new and the old.”
verses.textLa: Ait illis: Ideo omnis scriba doctus in regno cælorum, similis est homini patrifamilias, qui profert de thesauro suo nova et vetera.

verses.textEn: And it happened that, when Jesus had completed these parables, he went away from there.
verses.textLa: Et factum est, cum consummasset Iesus parabolas istas, transiit inde.

verses.textEn: And arriving in his own country, he taught them in their synagogues, so much so that they wondered and said: “How can such wisdom and power be with this one?
verses.textLa: Et veniens in patriam suam, docebat eos in synagogis eorum, ita ut mirarentur, et dicerent: Unde huic sapientia hæc, et virtutes?

verses.textEn: Is this not the son of a workman? Is not his mother called Mary, and his brothers, James, and Joseph, and Simon, and Jude?
verses.textLa: Nonne hic est fabri filius? Nonne mater eius dicitur Maria, et fratres eius, Iacobus, et Ioseph, et Simon, et Iudas?

verses.textEn: And his sisters, are they not all with us? Therefore, from where has this one obtained all these things?”
verses.textLa: Et sorores eius, nonne omnes apud nos sunt? Unde ergo huic omnia ista?

verses.textEn: And they took offense at him. But Jesus said to them, “A prophet is not without honor, except in his own country and in his own house.”
verses.textLa: Et scandalizabantur in eo. Iesus autem dixit eis: Non est propheta sine honore, nisi in patria sua, et in domo sua.

verses.textEn: And he did not work many miracles there, because of their unbelief.
verses.textLa: Et non fecit ibi virtutes multas propter incredulitatem illorum.

verses.textEn: In that time, Herod the Tetrarch heard the news about Jesus.
verses.textLa: In illo tempore audivit Herodes tetrarcha fama Iesu:

verses.textEn: And he said to his servants: “This is John the Baptist. He has risen from the dead, and that is why miracles are at work in him.”
verses.textLa: et ait pueris suis: Hic est Ioannes Baptista: ipse surrexit a mortuis, et ideo virtutes operantur in eo.

verses.textEn: For Herod had apprehended John, and bound him, and put him in prison, because of Herodias, the wife of his brother.
verses.textLa: Herodes enim tenuit Ioannem, et alligavit eum: et posuit in carcerem propter Herodiadem uxorem fratris sui.

verses.textEn: For John was telling him, “It is not lawful for you to have her.”
verses.textLa: Dicebat enim illi Ioannes: Non licet tibi habere eam.

verses.textEn: And though he wanted to kill him, he feared the people, because they held him to be a prophet.
verses.textLa: Et volens illum occidere, timuit populum: quia sicut prophetam eum habebant.

verses.textEn: Then, on Herod’s birthday, the daughter of Herodias danced in their midst, and it pleased Herod.
verses.textLa: Die autem natalis Herodis saltavit filia Herodiadis in medio, et placuit Herodi.

verses.textEn: And so he promised with an oath to give her whatever she would ask of him.
verses.textLa: Unde cum iuramento pollicitus est ei dare quodcumque postulasset ab eo.

verses.textEn: But, having been advised by her mother, she said, “Give me here, on a platter, the head of John the Baptist.”
verses.textLa: At illa præmonita a matre sua, Da mihi, inquit, hic in disco caput Ioannis Baptistæ.
verses.notes: The translation ‘here and now’ could also be rendered as ‘in this place’ or ‘in this circumstance.’

verses.textEn: And the king was greatly saddened. But because of his oath, and because of those who sat at table with him, he ordered it to be given.
verses.textLa: Et contristatus est rex: propter iuramentum autem, et eos, qui pariter recumbebant, iussit dari.

verses.textEn: And he sent and beheaded John in prison.
verses.textLa: Misitque et decollavit Ioannem in carcere.

verses.textEn: And his head was brought on a platter, and it was given to the girl, and she brought it to her mother.
verses.textLa: Et allatum est caput eius in disco, et datum est puellæ, et attulit matri suæ.

verses.textEn: And his disciples approached and took the body, and they buried it. And arriving, they reported it to Jesus.
verses.textLa: Et accedentes discipuli eius, tulerunt corpus eius, et sepelierunt illud: et venientes nunciaverunt Iesu.

verses.textEn: When Jesus had heard it, he withdrew from there by boat, to a deserted place by himself. And when the crowds had heard of it, they followed him on foot from the cities.
verses.textLa: Quod cum audisset Iesus, secessit inde in navicula, in locum desertum seorsum: et cum audissent turbæ, secutæ sunt eum pedestres de civitatibus.

verses.textEn: And going out, he saw a great multitude, and he took pity on them, and he cured their sick.
verses.textLa: Et exiens vidit turbam multam, et misertus est eis, et curavit languidos eorum.

verses.textEn: And when evening had arrived, his disciples approached him, saying: “This is a deserted place, and the hour has now passed. Dismiss the crowds, so that, by going into the towns, they may buy food for themselves.”
verses.textLa: Vespere autem facto, accesserunt ad eum discipuli eius, dicentes: Desertus est locus, et hora iam præteriit: dimitte turbas, ut euntes in castella, emant sibi escas.

verses.textEn: But Jesus said to them: “They have no need to go. Give them something to eat yourselves.”
verses.textLa: Iesus autem dixit eis: Non habent necesse ire: date illis vos manducare.

verses.textEn: They answered him, “We have nothing here, except five loaves and two fish.”
verses.textLa: Responderunt ei: Non habemus hic nisi quinque panes, et duos pisces.

verses.textEn: He said to them, “Bring them here to me.”
verses.textLa: Qui ait eis: Afferte mihi illos huc.

verses.textEn: And when he had ordered the multitude to sit down upon the grass, he took the five loaves and the two fish, and gazing up to heaven, he blessed and broke and gave the bread to the disciples, and then the disciples to the multitudes.
verses.textLa: Et cum iussisset turbam discumbere super fœnum, acceptis quinque panibus, et duobus piscibus, aspiciens in cælum benedixit, et fregit, et dedit discipulis panes, discipuli autem turbis.

verses.textEn: And they all ate and were satisfied. And they took up the remnants: twelve baskets full of fragments.
verses.textLa: Et manducaverunt omnes, et saturati sunt. Et tulerunt reliquias, duodecim cophinos fragmentorum plenos.

verses.textEn: Now the number of those who ate was five thousand men, besides women and children.
verses.textLa: Manducantium autem fuit numerus, quinque millia virorum, exceptis mulieribus, et parvulis.

verses.textEn: And Jesus promptly compelled his disciples to climb into the boat, and to precede him in crossing the sea, while he dismissed the crowds.
verses.textLa: Et statim compulit Iesus discipulos ascendere in naviculam, et præcedere eum trans fretum, donec dimitteret turbas.

verses.textEn: And having dismissed the multitude, he ascended alone onto a mountain to pray. And when evening arrived, he was alone there.
verses.textLa: Et dimissa turba, ascendit in montem solus orare. Vespere autem facto solus erat ibi.

verses.textEn: But in the midst of the sea, the boat was being tossed about by the waves. For the wind was against them.
verses.textLa: Navicula autem in medio mari iactabatur fluctibus: erat enim contrarius ventus.

verses.textEn: Then, in the fourth watch of the night, he came to them, walking upon the sea.
verses.textLa: Quarta enim vigilia noctis, venit ad eos ambulans super mare.

verses.textEn: And seeing him walking upon the sea, they were disturbed, saying: “It must be an apparition.” And they cried out, because of fear.
verses.textLa: Et videntes eum super mare ambulantem, turbati sunt, dicentes: Quia phantasma est. Et præ timore clamaverunt.

verses.textEn: And immediately, Jesus spoke to them, saying: “Have faith. It is I. Do not be afraid.”
verses.textLa: Statimque Iesus locutus est eis, dicens: Habete fiduciam: ego sum, nolite timere.
verses.notes: Ego sum can also be translated as ‘I am.’

verses.textEn: Then Peter responded by saying, “Lord, if it is you, order me to come to you over the waters.”
verses.textLa: Respondens autem Petrus dixit: Domine, si tu es, iube me ad te venire super aquas.

verses.textEn: And he said, “Come.” And Peter, descending from the boat, walked over the water, so as to go to Jesus.
verses.textLa: At ipse ait: Veni. Et descendens Petrus de navicula, ambulabat super aquam ut veniret ad Iesum.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, seeing that the wind was strong, he was afraid. And as he began to sink, he cried out, saying: “Lord, save me.”
verses.textLa: Videns vero ventum validum, timuit: et cum cœpisset mergi, clamavit dicens: Domine, salvum me fac.

verses.textEn: And immediately Jesus extended his hand and took hold of him. And he said to him, “O little in faith, why did you doubt?”
verses.textLa: Et continuo Iesus extendens manum, apprehendit eum: et ait illi: Modicæ fidei, quare dubitasti?

verses.textEn: And when they had ascended into the boat, the wind ceased.
verses.textLa: Et cum ascendissent in naviculam, cessavit ventus.

verses.textEn: Then those who were in the boat drew near and adored him, saying: “Truly, you are the Son of God.”
verses.textLa: Qui autem in navicula erant, venerunt, et adoraverunt eum, dicentes: Vere, Filius Dei es.

verses.textEn: And having crossed the sea, they arrived in the land of Genesaret.
verses.textLa: Et cum transfretassent, venerunt in terram Genesar.

verses.textEn: And when the men of that place had recognized him, they sent into all that region, and they brought to him all who had maladies.
verses.textLa: Et cum cognovissent eum viri loci illius, miserunt in universam regionem illam, et obtulerunt ei omnes male habentes:

verses.textEn: And they petitioned him, so that they might touch even the hem of his garment. And as many as touched it were made whole.
verses.textLa: et rogabant eum ut vel fimbriam vestimenti eius tangerent. Et quicumque tetigerunt, salvi facti sunt.

verses.textEn: Then the scribes and the Pharisees came to him from Jerusalem, saying:
verses.textLa: Tunc accesserunt ad eum ab Ierosolymis Scribæ, et Pharisæi, dicentes:

verses.textEn: “Why do your disciples transgress the tradition of the elders? For they do not wash their hands when they eat bread.”
verses.textLa: Quare discipuli tui transgrediuntur traditionem seniorum? non enim lavant manus suas cum panem manducant.

verses.textEn: But responding, he said to them: “And why do you transgress the commandment of God for the sake of your tradition? For God said:
verses.textLa: Ipse autem respondens ait illis: Quare et vos transgredimini mandatum Dei propter traditionem vestram? Nam Deus dixit:

verses.textEn: ‘Honor your father and mother,’ and, ‘Whoever will have cursed father or mother shall die a death.’
verses.textLa: Honora patrem, et matrem. Et: Qui maledixerit patri, vel matri, morte moriatur.

verses.textEn: But you say: ‘If anyone will have said to father or mother, “It is dedicated, so that whatever is from me will benefit you,”
verses.textLa: Vos autem dicitis: Quicumque dixerit patri, vel matri, Munus, quodcumque est ex me, tibi proderit,
verses.notes: In other words, any gift that would have been given to one’s parents is still counted as benefiting them, even though it is not given to them.

verses.textEn: then he shall not honor his father or his mother.’ So have you nullified the commandment of God, for the sake of your tradition.
verses.textLa: et non honorificabit patrem suum, aut matrem suam: et irritum fecistis mandatum Dei propter traditionem vestram.

verses.textEn: Hypocrites! How well did Isaiah prophesy about you, saying:
verses.textLa: Hypocritæ, bene prophetavit de vobis Isaias, dicens:

verses.textEn: ‘This people honors me with their lips, but their heart is far from me.
verses.textLa: Populus hic labiis me honorat: cor autem eorum longe est a me.

verses.textEn: For in vain do they worship me, teaching the doctrines and commandments of men.’ ”
verses.textLa: Sine causa autem colunt me, docentes doctrinas, et mandata hominum.

verses.textEn: And having called the multitudes to him, he said to them: “Listen and understand.
verses.textLa: Et convocatis ad se turbis, dixit eis: Audite, et intelligite.

verses.textEn: A man is not defiled by what enters into the mouth, but by what proceeds from the mouth. This is what defiles a man.”
verses.textLa: Non quod intrat in os, coinquinat hominem: sed quod procedit ex ore, hoc coinquinat hominem.

verses.textEn: Then his disciples drew near and said to him, “Do you know that the Pharisees, upon hearing this word, were offended?”
verses.textLa: Tunc accedentes discipuli eius, dixerunt ei: Scis quia Pharisæi audito verbo hoc, scandalizati sunt?

verses.textEn: But in response he said: “Every plant which has not been planted by my heavenly Father shall be uprooted.
verses.textLa: At ille respondens ait: Omnis plantatio, quam non plantavit Pater meus cælestis, eradicabitur.

verses.textEn: Leave them alone. They are blind, and they lead the blind. But if the blind are in charge of the blind, both will fall into the pit.”
verses.textLa: Sinite illos: cæci sunt, et duces cæcorum. Cæcus autem si cæco ducatum præstet, ambo in foveam cadunt.

verses.textEn: And responding, Peter said to him, “Explain this parable to us.”
verses.textLa: Respondens autem Petrus dixit ei: Edissere nobis parabolam istam.

verses.textEn: But he said: “Are you, even now, without understanding?
verses.textLa: At ille dixit: Adhuc et vos sine intellectu estis?

verses.textEn: Do you not understand that everything that enters into the mouth goes into the gut, and is cast into the sewer?
verses.textLa: Non intelligitis quia omne, quod in os intrat, in ventrem vadit, et in secessum emittitur?

verses.textEn: But what proceeds from the mouth, goes forth from the heart, and those are the things that defile a man.
verses.textLa: Quæ autem procedunt de ore, de corde exeunt, et ea coinquinant hominem:

verses.textEn: For from the heart go out evil thoughts, murders, adulteries, fornications, thefts, false testimonies, blasphemies.
verses.textLa: de corde enim exeunt cogitationes malæ, homicidia, adulteria, fornicationes, furta, falsa testimonia, blasphemiæ.

verses.textEn: These are the things that defile a man. But to eat without washing hands does not defile a man.”
verses.textLa: Hæc sunt, quæ coinquinant hominem. Non lotis autem manibus manducare, non coinquinat hominem.

verses.textEn: And departing from there, Jesus withdrew into the areas of Tyre and Sidon.
verses.textLa: Et egressus inde Iesus secessit in partes Tyri, et Sidonis.

verses.textEn: And behold, a woman of Canaan, going out from those parts, cried out, saying to him: “Take pity on me, Lord, Son of David. My daughter is badly afflicted by a demon.”
verses.textLa: Et ecce mulier Chananæa a finibus illis egressa clamavit, dicens ei: Miserere mei Domine, Fili David: filia mea male a dæmonio vexatur.

verses.textEn: He did not say a word to her. And his disciples, drawing near, petitioned him, saying: “Dismiss her, for she is crying out after us.”
verses.textLa: Qui non respondit ei verbum. Et accedentes discipuli eius rogabant eum dicentes: Dimitte eam: quia clamat post nos.

verses.textEn: And responding, he said, “I was not sent except to the sheep who have fallen away from the house of Israel.”
verses.textLa: Ipse autem respondens ait: Non sum missus nisi ad oves, quæ perierunt domus Israel.

verses.textEn: But she approached and adored him, saying, “Lord, help me.”
verses.textLa: At illa venit, et adoravit eum, dicens: Domine, adiuva me.

verses.textEn: And responding, he said, “It is not good to take the bread of the children and cast it to the dogs.”
verses.textLa: Qui respondens ait: Non est bonum sumere panem filiorum, et mittere canibus.

verses.textEn: But she said, “Yes, Lord, but the young dogs also eat from the crumbs that fall from the table of their masters.”
verses.textLa: At illa dixit: Etiam Domine: nam et catelli edunt de micis, quæ cadunt de mensa dominorum suorum.

verses.textEn: Then Jesus, responding, said to her: “O woman, great is your faith. Let it be done for you just as you wish.” And her daughter was healed from that very hour.
verses.textLa: Tunc respondens Iesus, ait illi: O mulier, magna est fides tua: fiat tibi sicut vis. Et sanata est filia eius ex illa hora.

verses.textEn: And when Jesus had passed from there, he arrived beside the sea of Galilee. And ascending onto a mountain, he sat down there.
verses.textLa: Et cum transisset inde Iesus, venit secus Mare Galilææ: et ascendens in montem, sedebat ibi.

verses.textEn: And great multitudes came to him, having with them the mute, the blind, the lame, the disabled, and many others. And they cast them down at his feet, and he cured them,
verses.textLa: Et accesserunt ad eum turbæ multæ, habentes secum mutos, cæcos, claudos, debiles, et alios multos: et proiecerunt eos ad pedes eius, et curavit eos:

verses.textEn: so much so that the crowds wondered, seeing the mute speaking, the lame walking, the blind seeing. And they magnified the God of Israel.
verses.textLa: ita ut turbæ mirarentur videntes mutos loquentes, claudos ambulantes, cæcos videntes: et magnificabant Deum Israel.

verses.textEn: And Jesus, calling together his disciples, said: “I have compassion on the crowds, because they have persevered with me now for three days, and they do not have anything to eat. And I am not willing to dismiss them, fasting, lest they faint along the way.”
verses.textLa: Iesus autem, convocatis discipulis suis, dixit: Misereor turbæ, quia triduo iam perseverant mecum, et non habent quod manducent: et dimittere eos ieiunos nolo, ne deficiant in via.

verses.textEn: And the disciples said to him: “From where, then, in the desert, would we obtain enough bread to satisfy so a great multitude?”
verses.textLa: Et dicunt ei discipuli: Unde ergo nobis in deserto panes tantos, ut saturemus turbam tantam?

verses.textEn: And Jesus said to them, “How many loaves of bread do you have?” But they said, “Seven, and a few little fish.”
verses.textLa: Et ait illis Iesus: Quot habetis panes? At illi dixerunt: Septem, et paucos pisciculos.

verses.textEn: And he instructed the crowds to recline upon the ground.
verses.textLa: Et præcepit turbæ, ut discumberent super terram.

verses.textEn: And taking the seven loaves and the fish, and giving thanks, he broke and gave to his disciples, and the disciples gave to the people.
verses.textLa: Et accipiens septem panes, et pisces, et gratias agens, fregit, et dedit discipulis suis, et discipuli dederunt populo.

verses.textEn: And they all ate and were satisfied. And, from what was left over of the fragments, they took up seven full baskets.
verses.textLa: Et comederunt omnes, et saturati sunt. Et quod superfuit de fragmentis, tulerunt septem sportas plenas.

verses.textEn: But those who ate were four thousand men, plus children and women.
verses.textLa: Erant autem qui manducaverunt, quattuor millia hominum, extra parvulos, et mulieres.

verses.textEn: And having dismissed the crowd, he climbed into a boat. And he went into the coastal region of Magadan.
verses.textLa: Et, dimissa turba, ascendit in naviculam: et venit in fines Magedan.

verses.textEn: And Pharisees and Sadducees approached him to test him, and they asked him to show them a sign from heaven.
verses.textLa: Et accesserunt ad eum Pharisæi, et Sadducæi tentantes: et rogaverunt eum ut signum de cælo ostenderet eis.

verses.textEn: But he responded by saying to them: “When evening arrives, you say, ‘It will be calm, for the sky is red,’
verses.textLa: At ille respondens, ait illis: Facto vespere dicitis: Serenum erit, rubicundum est enim cælum.
verses.notes: This verse has an eschatological meaning, in that, prior to Christ’s return, the sky will appear red and the impious will claim that calm has arrived on earth. The evening is symbolic of a time of darkness on earth, when sinfulness reigns; yet they say about the evening that it will bring serenity. The morning is symbolic of a time of true light on earth, especially when Christ, the morning star, returns; yet they say about the morning that it brings trouble.

verses.textEn: and in the morning, ‘Today there will be a storm, for the sky is red and gloomy.’ So then, you know how to judge the appearance of the sky, but you are unable to know the signs of the times?
verses.textLa: Et mane: Hodie tempestas, rutilat enim triste cælum.

verses.textEn: An evil and adulterous generation seeks a sign. And a sign shall not be given to it, except the sign of the prophet Jonah.” And leaving them behind, he went away.
verses.textLa: Faciem ergo cæli diiudicare nostis: signa autem temporum non potestis scire? Generatio mala et adultera signum quærit: et signum non dabitur ei, nisi signum Ionæ prophetæ. Et relictis illis, abiit.

verses.textEn: And when his disciples went across the sea, they forgot to bring bread.
verses.textLa: Et cum venissent discipuli eius trans fretum, obliti sunt panes accipere.

verses.textEn: And he said to them, “Consider and beware of the leaven of the Pharisees and the Sadducees.”
verses.textLa: Qui dixit illis: Intuemini, et cavete a fermento Pharisæorum, et Sadducæorum.

verses.textEn: But they were thinking within themselves, saying, “It is because we have not brought bread.”
verses.textLa: At illi cogitabant intra se dicentes: Quia panes non accepimus.

verses.textEn: Then Jesus, knowing this, said: “Why do you consider within yourselves, O little in faith, that it is because you have no bread?
verses.textLa: Sciens autem Iesus, dixit: Quid cogitatis intra vos modicæ fidei, quia panes non habetis?

verses.textEn: Do you not yet understand, nor remember, the five loaves among the five thousand men, and how many containers you took up?
verses.textLa: Nondum intelligitis, neque recordamini quinque panum in quinque millia hominum, et quot cophinos sumpsistis?

verses.textEn: Or the seven loaves among the four thousand men, and how many baskets you took up?
verses.textLa: neque septem panum in quattuor millia hominum, et quot sportas sumpsistis?

verses.textEn: Why do you not understand that it was not because of bread that I said to you: Beware of the leaven of the Pharisees and the Sadducees?”
verses.textLa: Quare non intelligitis, quia non de pane dixi vobis: Cavete a fermento Pharisæorum, et Sadducæorum?

verses.textEn: Then they understood that he was not saying that they should beware of the leaven of bread, but of the doctrine of the Pharisees and the Sadducees.
verses.textLa: Tunc intellexerunt quia non dixerit cavendum a fermento panum, sed a doctrina Pharisæorum, et Sadducæorum.

verses.textEn: Then Jesus went into parts of Caesarea Philippi. And he questioned his disciples, saying, “Who do men say that the Son of man is?”
verses.textLa: Venit autem Iesus in partes Cæsareæ Philippi: et interrogabat discipulos suos, dicens: Quem dicunt homines esse Filium hominis?

verses.textEn: And they said, “Some say John the Baptist, and others say Elijah, still others say Jeremiah or one of the prophets.”
verses.textLa: At illi dixerunt: Alii Ioannem Baptistam, alii autem Eliam, alii vero Ieremiam, aut unum ex prophetis.

verses.textEn: Jesus said to them, “But who do you say that I am?”
verses.textLa: Dicit illis Iesus: Vos autem quem me esse dicitis?

verses.textEn: Simon Peter responded by saying, “You are the Christ, the Son of the living God.”
verses.textLa: Respondens Simon Petrus dixit: Tu es Christus, Filius Dei vivi.

verses.textEn: And in response, Jesus said to him: “Blessed are you, Simon son of Jonah. For flesh and blood has not revealed this to you, but my Father, who is in heaven.
verses.textLa: Respondens autem Iesus, dixit ei: Beatus es Simon Bar Iona: quia caro, et sanguis non revelavit tibi, sed Pater meus, qui in cælis est.

verses.textEn: And I say to you, that you are Peter, and upon this rock I will build my Church, and the gates of Hell shall not prevail against it.
verses.textLa: Et ego dico tibi, quia tu es Petrus, et super hanc petram ædificabo Ecclesiam meam, et portæ inferi non prævalebunt adversus eam.
verses.notes: The word ‘will’ is used when God or Christ ‘will’ do something. The word ‘shall’ has something of the meaning of ‘should’ to it, but God does not do things because He should, but because He Is Who Is.

verses.textEn: And I will give you the keys of the kingdom of heaven. And whatever you shall bind on earth shall be bound, even in heaven. And whatever you shall release on earth shall be released, even in heaven.”
verses.textLa: Et tibi dabo claves regni cælorum. Et quodcumque ligaveris super terram, erit ligatum et in cælis: et quodcumque solveris super terram, erit solutum et in cælis.

verses.textEn: Then he instructed his disciples that they should tell no one that he is Jesus the Christ.
verses.textLa: Tunc præcepit discipulis suis ut nemini dicerent quia ipse esset Iesus Christus.

verses.textEn: From that time, Jesus began to reveal to his disciples that it was necessary for him to go to Jerusalem, and to suffer much from the elders and the scribes and the leaders of the priests, and to be killed, and to rise again on the third day.
verses.textLa: Exinde cœpit Iesus ostendere discipulis suis, quia oporteret eum ire Ierosolymam, et multa pati a senioribus, et Scribis, et principibus sacerdotum, et occidi, et tertia die resurgere.

verses.textEn: And Peter, taking him aside, began to rebuke him, saying, “Lord, may it be far from you; this shall not happen to you.”
verses.textLa: Et assumens eum Petrus, cœpit increpare illum dicens: Absit a te, Domine: non erit tibi hoc.

verses.textEn: And turning away, Jesus said to Peter: “Get behind me, Satan; you are an obstacle to me. For you are not behaving according to what is of God, but according to what is of men.”
verses.textLa: Qui conversus, dixit Petro: Vade post me Satana, scandalum es mihi: quia non sapis ea, quæ Dei sunt, sed ea, quæ hominum.
verses.notes: Jesus literally turned his back to Peter at this point, according to the Latin text ‘Qui conversus.’

verses.textEn: Then Jesus said to his disciples: “If anyone is willing to come after me, let him deny himself, and take up his cross, and follow me.
verses.textLa: Tunc Iesus dixit discipulis suis: Si quis vult post me venire, abneget semetipsum, et tollat crucem suam, et sequatur me.

verses.textEn: For whoever would save his life, will lose it. But whoever will have lost his life for my sake, shall find it.
verses.textLa: Qui enim voluerit animam suam salvam facere, perdet eam. Qui autem perdiderit animam suam propter me, inveniet eam.

verses.textEn: For how does it benefit a man, if he gains the whole world, yet truly suffers damage to his soul? Or what shall a man give in exchange for his soul?
verses.textLa: Quid enim prodest homini, si mundum universum lucretur, animæ vero suæ detrimentum patiatur? Aut quam dabit homo commutationem pro anima sua?

verses.textEn: For the Son of man will arrive in the glory of his Father, with his Angels. And then he will repay each one according to his works.
verses.textLa: Filius enim hominis venturus est in gloria Patris sui cum Angelis suis: et tunc reddet unicuique secundum opera eius.

verses.textEn: Amen I say to you, there are some among those standing here, who shall not taste death, until they see the Son of man arriving in his reign.”
verses.textLa: Amen dico vobis, sunt quidam de hic stantibus, qui non gustabunt mortem, donec videant Filium hominis venientem in regno suo.

verses.textEn: And after six days, Jesus took Peter and James and his brother John, and he led them onto a lofty mountain separately.
verses.textLa: Et post dies sex assumit Iesus Petrum, et Iacobum, et Ioannem fratrem eius, et ducit illos in montem excelsum seorsum:

verses.textEn: And he was transfigured before them. And his face shined brightly like the sun. And his garments were made white like snow.
verses.textLa: et transfiguratus est ante eos. Et resplenduit facies eius sicut sol: vestimenta autem eius facta sunt alba sicut nix.

verses.textEn: And behold, there appeared to them Moses and Elijah, speaking with him.
verses.textLa: Et ecce apparuerunt illis Moyses, et Elias cum eo loquentes.

verses.textEn: And Peter responded by saying to Jesus: “Lord, it is good for us to be here. If you are willing, let us make three tabernacles here, one for you, one for Moses, and one for Elijah.”
verses.textLa: Respondens autem Petrus, dixit ad Iesum: Domine, bonum est nos hic esse: si vis, faciamus tria tabernacula, tibi unum, Moysi unum, et Eliæ unum.

verses.textEn: And while he was still speaking, behold, a shining cloud overshadowed them. And behold, there was a voice from the cloud, saying: “This is my beloved Son, with whom I am well pleased. Listen to him.”
verses.textLa: Adhuc eo loquente, ecce nubes lucida obumbravit eos. Et ecce vox de nube, dicens: Hic est Filius meus dilectus, in quo mihi bene complacui: ipsum audite.

verses.textEn: And the disciples, hearing this, fell prone on their face, and they were very afraid.
verses.textLa: Et audientes discipuli ceciderunt in faciem suam, et timuerunt valde.

verses.textEn: And Jesus drew near and touched them. And he said to them, “Rise up and do not be afraid.”
verses.textLa: Et accessit Iesus, et tetigit eos: dixitque eis: Surgite, et nolite timere.

verses.textEn: And lifting up their eyes, they saw no one, except Jesus alone.
verses.textLa: Levantes autem oculos suos, neminem viderunt, nisi solum Iesum.

verses.textEn: And as they were descending from the mountain, Jesus instructed them, saying, “Tell no one about the vision, until the Son of man has risen from the dead.”
verses.textLa: Et descendentibus illis de monte, præcepit eis Iesus, dicens: Nemini dixeritis visionem, donec Filius hominis a mortuis resurgat.

verses.textEn: And his disciples questioned him, saying, “Why then do the scribes say that it is necessary for Elijah to arrive first?”
verses.textLa: Et interrogaverunt eum discipuli, dicentes: Quid ergo scribæ dicunt quod Eliam oporteat primum venire?

verses.textEn: But in response, he said to them: “Elijah, indeed, shall arrive and restore all things.
verses.textLa: At ille respondens, ait eis: Elias quidem venturus est, et restituet omnia.

verses.textEn: But I say to you, that Elijah has already arrived, and they did not recognize him, but they did whatever they wanted to him. So also shall the Son of man suffer from them.”
verses.textLa: Dico autem vobis, quia Elias iam venit, et non cognoverunt eum, sed fecerunt in eo quæcumque voluerunt. Sic et Filius hominis passurus est ab eis.

verses.textEn: Then the disciples understood that he had spoken to them about John the Baptist.
verses.textLa: Tunc intellexerunt discipuli, quia de Ioanne Baptista dixisset eis.

verses.textEn: And when he had arrived at the multitude, a man approached him, falling to his knees before him, saying: “Lord, take pity on my son, for he is an epileptic, and he suffers harm. For he frequently falls into fire, and often also into water.
verses.textLa: Et cum venisset ad turbam, accessit ad eum homo genibus provolutus ante eum, dicens: Domine, miserere filio meo, quia lunaticus est, et male patitur: nam sæpe cadit in ignem, et crebro in aquam.
verses.notes: The word ‘lunaticus’ refers to any type of problem with the brain or mind, from mental illness even to epilepsy.

verses.textEn: And I brought him to your disciples, but they were not able to cure him.”
verses.textLa: Et obtuli eum discipulis tuis, et non potuerunt curare eum.

verses.textEn: Then Jesus responded by saying: “What an unbelieving and perverse generation! How long shall I be with you? How long shall I endure you? Bring him here to me.”
verses.textLa: Respondens autem Iesus, ait: O generatio incredula, et perversa, quousque ero vobiscum? usquequo patiar vos? Afferte huc illum ad me.

verses.textEn: And Jesus rebuked him, and the demon went out of him, and the boy was cured from that hour.
verses.textLa: Et increpavit illum Iesus, et exiit ab eo dæmonium, et curatus est puer ex illa hora.

verses.textEn: Then the disciples approached Jesus privately and said, “Why were we unable to cast him out?”
verses.textLa: Tunc accesserunt discipuli ad Iesum secreto, et dixerunt: Quare nos non potuimus eiicere illum?

verses.textEn: Jesus said to them: “Because of your unbelief. Amen I say to you, certainly, if you will have faith like a grain of mustard seed, you will say to this mountain, ‘Move from here to there,’ and it shall move. And nothing will be impossible for you.
verses.textLa: Dixit illis Iesus: Propter incredulitatem vestram. Amen quippe dico vobis, si habueritis fidem, sicut granum sinapis, dicetis monti huic, Transi hinc illuc, et transibit, et nihil impossibile erit vobis.

verses.textEn: But this kind is not cast out, except through prayer and fasting.”
verses.textLa: Hoc autem genus non eiicitur nisi per orationem, et ieiunium.

verses.textEn: And when they were conversing together in Galilee, Jesus said to them: “The Son of man shall be delivered into the hands of men.
verses.textLa: Conversantibus autem eis in Galilæa, dixit illis Iesus: Filius hominis tradendus est in manus hominum:

verses.textEn: And they will kill him, but he will rise again on the third day.” And they were extremely saddened.
verses.textLa: et occident eum, et tertia die resurget. Et contristati sunt vehementer.

verses.textEn: And when they had arrived at Capernaum, those who collected the half shekel approached Peter, and they said to him, “Doesn’t your Teacher pay the half shekel?”
verses.textLa: Et cum venissent Capharnaum, accesserunt qui didrachma accipiebant, ad Petrum, et dixerunt ei: Magister vester non solvit didrachma?

verses.textEn: He said, “Yes.” And when he had entered into the house, Jesus went before him, saying: “How does it seem to you, Simon? The kings of the earth, from whom do they receive tribute or the census tax: from their own sons or from foreigners?”
verses.textLa: Ait: Etiam. Et cum intrasset in domum, prævenit eum Iesus, dicens: Quid tibi videtur Simon? Reges terræ a quibus accipiunt tributum vel censum? a filiis suis, an ab alienis?

verses.textEn: And he said, “From foreigners.” Jesus said to him: “Then the sons are free.
verses.textLa: Et ille dixit: Ab alienis. Dixit illi Iesus: Ergo liberi sunt filii.

verses.textEn: But so that we may not become an obstacle to them: go to the sea, and cast in a hook, and take the first fish that is brought up, and when you have opened its mouth, you will find a shekel. Take it and give it to them, for me and for you.”
verses.textLa: Ut autem non scandalizemus eos, vade ad mare, et mitte hamum: et eum piscem, qui primus ascenderit, tolle: et aperto ore eius, invenies staterem: illum sumens, da eis pro me, et te.

verses.textEn: In that hour, the disciples drew near to Jesus, saying, “Whom do you consider to be greater in the kingdom of heaven?”
verses.textLa: In illa hora accesserunt discipuli ad Iesum, dicentes: Quis putas, maior est in regno cælorum?

verses.textEn: And Jesus, calling to himself a little child, placed him in their midst.
verses.textLa: Et advocans Iesus parvulum, statuit eum in medio eorum,

verses.textEn: And he said: “Amen I say to you, unless you change and become like little children, you shall not enter into the kingdom of heaven.
verses.textLa: et dixit: Amen dico vobis, nisi conversi fueritis, et efficiamini sicut parvuli, non intrabitis in regnum cælorum.

verses.textEn: Therefore, whoever will have humbled himself like this little child, such a one is greater in the kingdom of heaven.
verses.textLa: Quicumque ergo humiliaverit se sicut parvulus iste, hic est maior in regno cælorum.

verses.textEn: And whoever shall accept one such little child in my name, accepts me.
verses.textLa: Et qui susceperit unum parvulum talem in nomine meo, me suscipit.

verses.textEn: But whoever will have led astray one of these little ones, who trust in me, it would be better for him to have a great millstone hung around his neck, and to be submerged in the depths of the sea.
verses.textLa: Qui autem scandalizaverit unum de pusillis istis, qui in me credunt, expedit ei ut suspendatur mola asinaria in collo eius, et demergatur in profundum maris.
verses.notes: The phrase ‘mola asinaria’ refers to the type of millstone that is so large as to require a team of donkeys to turn it for grinding; in other words, it is a very large millstone.

verses.textEn: Woe to a world that leads people astray! Although it is necessary for temptations to arise, nevertheless: Woe to that man through whom temptation arises!
verses.textLa: Væ mundo a scandalis. Necesse est enim ut veniant scandala: verumtamen væ homini illi, per quem scandalum venit.

verses.textEn: So if your hand or your foot leads you to sin, cut it off and cast it away from you. It is better for you to enter into life disabled or lame, than to be sent into eternal fire having two hands or two feet.
verses.textLa: Si autem manus tua, vel pes tuus scandalizat te: abscide eum, et proiice abs te: bonum tibi est ad vitam ingredi debilem, vel claudum, quam duas manus, vel duos pedes habentem mitti in ignem æternum.

verses.textEn: And if your eye leads you to sin, root it out and cast it away from you. It is better for you to enter into life with one eye, than to be sent into the fires of Hell having two eyes.
verses.textLa: Et si oculus tuus scandalizat te, erue eum, et proiice abs te: bonum tibi est cum uno oculo in vitam intrare, quam duos oculos habentem mitti in Gehennam ignis.

verses.textEn: See to it that you do not despise even one of these little ones. For I say to you, that their Angels in heaven continually look upon the face of my Father, who is in heaven.
verses.textLa: Videte ne contemnatis unum ex his pusillis: dico enim vobis, quia Angeli eorum in cælis semper vident faciem Patris mei, qui in cælis est.
verses.notes: The holy Angels have the Beatific vision.

verses.textEn: For the Son of man has come to save what had been lost.
verses.textLa: Venit enim Filius hominis salvare quod perierat.

verses.textEn: How does it seem to you? If someone has one hundred sheep, and if one of them has gone astray, should he not leave behind the ninety-nine in the mountains, and go out to seek what has gone astray?
verses.textLa: Quid vobis videtur? Si fuerint alicui centum oves, et erravit una ex eis: nonne relinquit nonaginta novem in montibus, et vadit quærere eam, quæ erravit?

verses.textEn: And if he should happen to find it: Amen I say to you, that he has more joy over that one, than over the ninety-nine which did not go astray.
verses.textLa: Et si contigerit ut inveniat eam: Amen dico vobis, quia gaudet super eam magis quam super nonaginta novem, quæ non erraverunt.

verses.textEn: Even so, it is not the will before your Father, who is in heaven, that one of these little ones should be lost.
verses.textLa: Sic non est voluntas ante Patrem vestrum, qui in cælis est, ut pereat unus de pusillis istis.

verses.textEn: But if your brother has sinned against you, go and correct him, between you and him alone. If he listens to you, you will have regained your brother.
