verses.textLa: Si autem peccaverit in te frater tuus, vade, et corripe eum inter te, et ipsum solum. Si te audierit, lucratus eris fratrem tuum.

verses.textEn: But if he will not listen you, invite with you one or two more, so that every word may stand by the mouth of two or three witnesses.
verses.textLa: Si autem te non audierit, adhibe tecum adhuc unum, vel duos, ut in ore duorum, vel trium testium stet omne verbum.
verses.notes: The Teaching of the Church stands by the two witnesses of Tradition and Scripture, and by the third witness of the Sacred Magisterium.

verses.textEn: And if he will not listen to them, tell the Church. But if he will not listen to the Church, let him be to you like the pagan and the tax collector.
verses.textLa: Quod si non audierit eos: dic Ecclesiæ. Si autem Ecclesiam non audierit: sit tibi sicut ethnicus, et publicanus.

verses.textEn: Amen I say to you, whatever you will have bound on earth, shall be bound also in heaven, and whatever you will have released on earth, shall be released also in heaven.
verses.textLa: Amen dico vobis, quæcumque alligaveritis super terram, erunt ligata et in cælo: et quæcumque solveritis super terram, erunt soluta et in cælo.

verses.textEn: Again I say to you, that if two of those among you have agreed on earth, about anything whatsoever that they have requested, it shall be done for them by my Father, who is in heaven.
verses.textLa: Iterum dico vobis, quia si duo ex vobis consenserint super terram, de omni re quamcumque petierint, fiet illis a Patre meo, qui in cælis est.

verses.textEn: For wherever two or three are gathered in my name, there am I, in their midst.”
verses.textLa: Ubi enim sunt duo, vel tres congregati in nomine meo, ibi sum in medio eorum.

verses.textEn: Then Peter, drawing near to him, said: “Lord, how many times shall my brother sin against me, and I forgive him? Even seven times?”
verses.textLa: Tunc accedens Petrus ad eum, dixit: Domine quoties peccabit in me frater meus, et dimittam ei? usque septies?

verses.textEn: Jesus said to him: “I do not say to you, even seven times, but even seventy times seven times.
verses.textLa: Dicit illi Iesus: Non dico tibi usque septies: sed usque septuagies septies.

verses.textEn: Therefore, the kingdom of heaven is compared to a man who was king, who wanted to take account of his servants.
verses.textLa: Ideo assimilatum est regnum cælorum homini regi, qui voluit rationem ponere cum servis suis.

verses.textEn: And when he had begun taking account, one was brought to him who owed him ten thousand talents.
verses.textLa: Et cum cœpisset rationem ponere, oblatus est ei unus, qui debebat ei decem millia talenta.
verses.notes: One talent (probably of silver, in this case) was equivalent to about 25 or so kilograms, so this was a huge sum of money. Also, to owe this large a sum, he would have to be one of the nobility, not the type of servant who did manual labor.

verses.textEn: But since he did not have any way to repay it, his lord ordered him to be sold, with his wife and children, and all that he had, in order to repay it.
verses.textLa: Cum autem non haberet unde redderet, iussit eum dominus eius venundari, et uxorem eius, et filios, et omnia quæ habebat, et reddi.

verses.textEn: But that servant, falling prostrate, begged him, saying, ‘Have patience with me, and I will repay it all to you.’
verses.textLa: Procidens autem servus ille, orabat eum, dicens: Patientiam habe in me, et omnia reddam tibi.

verses.textEn: Then the lord of that servant, being moved with pity, released him, and he forgave his debt.
verses.textLa: Misertus autem dominus servi illius, dimisit eum, et debitum dimisit ei.

verses.textEn: But when that servant departed, he found one of his fellow servants who owed him one hundred denarius. And taking hold of him, he choked him, saying: ‘Repay what you owe.’
verses.textLa: Egressus autem servus ille invenit unum de conservis suis, qui debebat ei centum denarios: et tenens suffocavit eum, dicens: Redde quod debes.

verses.textEn: And his fellow servant, falling prostrate, petitioned him, saying: ‘Have patience with me, and I will repay it all to you.’
verses.textLa: Et procidens conservus eius, rogabat eum, dicens: Patientiam habe in me, et omnia reddam tibi.

verses.textEn: But he was not willing. Instead, he went out and had him sent to prison, until he would repay the debt.
verses.textLa: Ille autem noluit: sed abiit, et misit eum in carcerem donec redderet debitum.

verses.textEn: Now his fellow servants, seeing what was done, were greatly saddened, and they went and reported to their lord all that was done.
verses.textLa: Videntes autem conservi eius quæ fiebant, contristati sunt valde: et venerunt, et narraverunt domino suo omnia quæ facta fuerant.

verses.textEn: Then his lord called him, and he said to him: ‘You wicked servant, I forgave you all your debt, because you pleaded with me.
verses.textLa: Tunc vocavit illum dominus suus: et ait illi: Serve nequam, omne debitum dimisi tibi quoniam rogasti me:

verses.textEn: Therefore, should you not also have had compassion on your fellow servant, just as I also had compassion on you?’
verses.textLa: nonne ergo oportuit et te misereri conservi tui, sicut et ego tui misertus sum?

verses.textEn: And his lord, being angry, handed him over to the torturers, until he repaid the entire debt.
verses.textLa: Et iratus dominus eius tradidit eum tortoribus, quoadusque redderet universum debitum.

verses.textEn: So, too, shall my heavenly Father do to you, if each one of you will not forgive his brother from your hearts.”
verses.textLa: Sic et Pater meus cælestis faciet vobis, si non remiseritis unusquisque fratri suo de cordibus vestris.

verses.textEn: And it happened that, when Jesus had completed these words, he moved away from Galilee, and he arrived within the borders of Judea, across the Jordan.
verses.textLa: Et factum est, cum consumasset Iesus sermones istos, migravit a Galilæa, et venit in fines Iudææ trans Iordanem,

verses.textEn: And great crowds followed him, and he healed them there.
verses.textLa: et secutæ sunt eum turbæ multæ, et curavit eos ibi.

verses.textEn: And the Pharisees approached him, testing him, and saying, “Is it lawful for a man to separate from his wife, no matter what the cause?”
verses.textLa: Et accesserunt ad eum Pharisæi tentantes eum, et dicentes: Si licet homini dimittere uxorem suam, quacumque ex causa?

verses.textEn: And he said to them in response, “Have you not read that he who made man from the beginning, made them male and female?” And he said:
verses.textLa: Qui respondens, ait eis: Non legistis, quia qui fecit hominem ab initio, masculum, et feminam fecit eos? Et dixit:

verses.textEn: “For this reason, a man shall separate from father and mother, and he shall cling to his wife, and these two shall become one flesh.
verses.textLa: Propter hoc dimittet homo patrem, et matrem, et adhærebit uxori suæ, et erunt duo in carne una.

verses.textEn: And so, now they are not two, but one flesh. Therefore, what God has joined together, let no man separate.”
verses.textLa: Itaque iam non sunt duo, sed una caro. Quod ergo Deus coniunxit, homo non separet.

verses.textEn: They said to him, “Then why did Moses command him to give a bill of divorce, and to separate?”
verses.textLa: Dicunt illi: Quid ergo Moyses mandavit dare libellum repudii, et dimittere?

verses.textEn: He said to them: “Although Moses permitted you to separate from your wives, due to the hardness of your heart, it was not that way from the beginning.
verses.textLa: Ait illis: Quoniam Moyses ad duritiam cordis vestri permisit vobis dimittere uxores vestras: ab initio autem non fuit sic.

verses.textEn: And I say to you, that whoever will have separated from his wife, except because of fornication, and who will have married another, commits adultery, and whoever will have married her who has been separated, commits adultery.”
verses.textLa: Dico autem vobis, quia quicumque dimiserit uxorem suam, nisi ob fornicationem, et aliam duxerit, mœchatur: et qui dimissam duxerit, mœchatur.

verses.textEn: His disciples said to him, “If such is the case for a man with a wife, then it is not expedient to marry.”
verses.textLa: Dicunt ei discipuli eius: Si ita est causa hominis cum uxore, non expedit nubere.

verses.textEn: And he said to them: “Not everyone is able to grasp this word, but only those to whom it has been given.
verses.textLa: Qui dixit illis: Non omnes capiunt verbum istud, sed quibus datum est.

verses.textEn: For there are chaste persons who were born so from their mother’s womb, and there are chaste persons who have been made so by men, and there are chaste persons who have made themselves chaste for the sake of the kingdom of heaven. Whoever is able to grasp this, let him grasp it.”
verses.textLa: Sunt enim eunuchi, qui de matris utero sic nati sunt: et sunt eunuchi, qui facti sunt ab hominibus: et sunt eunuchi, qui seipsos castraverunt propter regnum cælorum. Qui potest capere capiat.
verses.notes: The translation here prefers ‘chaste persons’ over eunuchs or celibate persons for a number of reasons. First, the term eunuch is used figuratively by Christ, as is the term ‘castraverunt’ (castrated). Second, the term eunuch is obscure today. Third, this passage began with a teaching on the proper behavior of married persons, so it is not solely about virgins or celibate clergy and religious. The term ‘chaste persons’ has sufficient breadth and depth, and is an accurate representation of the meaning of the term.

verses.textEn: Then they brought to him little children, so that he would place his hands upon them and pray. But the disciples rebuked them.
verses.textLa: Tunc oblati sunt ei parvuli, ut manus eis imponeret, et oraret. Discipuli autem increpabant eos.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, Jesus said to them: “Allow the little children to come to me, and do not choose to prohibit them. For the kingdom of heaven is among such as these.”
verses.textLa: Iesus vero ait eis: Sinite parvulos, et nolite eos prohibere ad me venire: talium est enim regnum cælorum.

verses.textEn: And when he had imposed his hands upon them, he went away from there.
verses.textLa: Et cum imposuisset eis manus, abiit inde.

verses.textEn: And behold, someone approached and said to him, “Good Teacher, what good should I do, so that I may have eternal life?”
verses.textLa: Et ecce unus accedens, ait illi: Magister bone, quid boni faciam ut habeam vitam æternam?

verses.textEn: And he said to him: “Why do you question me about what is good? One is good: God. But if you wish to enter into life, observe the commandments.”
verses.textLa: Qui dixit ei: Quid me interrogas de bono? Unus est bonus, Deus. Si autem vis ad vitam ingredi, serva mandata.

verses.textEn: He said to him, “Which?” And Jesus said: “You shall not murder. You shall not commit adultery. You shall not steal. You shall not give false testimony.
verses.textLa: Dicit illi: Quæ? Iesus autem dixit: Non homicidium facies: Non adulterabis: Non facies furtum: Non falsum testimonium dices:
verses.notes: Notice that Jesus specifically says ‘murder’ (homicidium), not ‘kill.’ Therefore, the Old Testament translation of the commandment as ‘You shall not murder’ is correct.

verses.textEn: Honor your father and your mother. And, you shall love your neighbor as yourself.”
verses.textLa: Honora patrem tuum, et matrem tuam, et diliges proximum tuum sicut teipsum.

verses.textEn: The young man said to him: “All these I have kept from my childhood. What is still lacking for me?”
verses.textLa: Dicit illi adolescens: Omnia hæc custodivi a iuventute mea, quid adhuc mihi deest?

verses.textEn: Jesus said to him: “If you are willing to be perfect, go, sell what you have, and give to the poor, and then you will have treasure in heaven. And come, follow me.”
verses.textLa: Ait illi Iesus: Si vis perfectus esse, vade, vende quæ habes, et da pauperibus, et habebis thesaurum in cælo: et veni, sequere me.

verses.textEn: And when the young man had heard this word, he went away sad, for he had many possessions.
verses.textLa: Cum audisset autem adolescens verbum, abiit tristis: erat enim habens multas possessiones.

verses.textEn: Then Jesus said to his disciples: “Amen, I say to you, that the wealthy shall enter with difficulty into the kingdom of heaven.
verses.textLa: Iesus autem dixit discipulis suis: Amen dico vobis, quia dives difficile intrabit in regnum cælorum.

verses.textEn: And again I say to you, it is easier for a camel to pass through the eye of a needle, than for the wealthy to enter into the kingdom of heaven.”
verses.textLa: Et iterum dico vobis: Facilius est camelum per foramen acus transire, quam divitem intrare in regnum cælorum.

verses.textEn: And upon hearing this, the disciples wondered greatly, saying: “Then who will be able to be saved?”
verses.textLa: Auditis autem his, discipuli mirabantur valde, dicentes: Quis ergo poterit salvus esse?

verses.textEn: But Jesus, gazing at them, said to them: “With men, this is impossible. But with God, all things are possible.”
verses.textLa: Aspiciens autem Iesus, dixit illis: Apud homines hoc impossibile est: apud Deum autem omnia possibilia sunt.
verses.notes: It is often said, by the foolish, that the camel in this saying is literally a camel, and that the 'eye of a needle' is a particular gate into the city of Jerusalem. They claim that Jesus was only referring to getting a camel through that small gateway, when he expressed how hard it is for the wealthy to enter the kingdom of God. But even though that gateway is narrow, it is not too difficult to get a camel through it. Perhaps it happened on a near daily basis. If this was the meaning of the saying, then it would not seem too difficult for the wealthy to enter heaven, and the disciples would be foolish to say 'Then who will be able to be saved?' And again, if so, then Jesus would not have said that it was impossible for men. So the saying has another meaning. It is a literal expression of the miraculous power of God. For a wealthy person to be saved, apart from the infinite mercy of God is impossible, nearly as impossible as literally passing a camel through the eye of a needle. But both acts can be done by the power of God.

verses.textEn: Then Peter responded by saying to him: “Behold, we have left behind all things, and we have followed you. So then, what will be for us?”
verses.textLa: Tunc respondens Petrus, dixit ei: Ecce nos reliquimus omnia, et secuti sumus te: quid ergo erit nobis?

verses.textEn: And Jesus said to them: “Amen I say to you, that at the resurrection, when the Son of man shall sit on the seat of his majesty, those of you who have followed me shall also sit on twelve seats, judging the twelve tribes of Israel.
verses.textLa: Iesus autem dixit illis: Amen dico vobis, quod vos, qui secuti estis me, in regeneratione cum sederit Filius hominis in sede maiestatis suæ, sedebitis et vos super sedes duodecim, iudicantes duodecim tribus Israel.

verses.textEn: And anyone who has left behind home, or brothers, or sisters, or father, or mother, or wife, or children, or land, for the sake of my name, shall receive one hundred times more, and shall possess eternal life.
verses.textLa: Et omnis, qui reliquerit domum, vel fratres, aut sorores, aut patrem, aut matrem, aut uxorem, aut filios, aut agros propter nomen meum, centuplum accipiet, et vitam æternam possidebit.

verses.textEn: But many of those who are first shall be last, and the last shall be first.”
verses.textLa: Multi autem erunt primi novissimi, et novissimi primi.

verses.textEn: “The kingdom of heaven is like the father of a family who went out in early morning to lead workers into his vineyard.
verses.textLa: Simile est regnum cælorum homini patrifamilias, qui exiit primo mane conducere operarios in vineam suam.

verses.textEn: Then, having made an agreement with the workers for one denarius per day, he sent them into his vineyard.
verses.textLa: Conventione autem facta cum operariis ex denario diurno, misit eos in vineam suam.

verses.textEn: And going out about the third hour, he saw others standing idle in the marketplace.
verses.textLa: Et egressus circa horam tertiam, vidit alios stantes in foro otiosos,

verses.textEn: And he said to them, ‘You may go into my vineyard, too, and what I will give you will be just.’
verses.textLa: et dixit illis: Ite et vos in vineam meam, et quod iustum fuerit dabo vobis.

verses.textEn: So they went forth. But again, he went out about the sixth, and about the ninth hour, and he acted similarly.
verses.textLa: Illi autem abierunt. Iterum autem exiit circa sextam et nonam horam: et fecit similiter.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, about the eleventh hour, he went out and found others standing, and he said to them, ‘Why have you stood here idle all day?’
verses.textLa: Circa undecimam vero exiit, et invenit alios stantes, et dicit illis: Quid hic statis tota die otiosi?

verses.textEn: They say to him, ‘Because no one has hired us.’ He said to them, ‘You also may go into my vineyard.’
verses.textLa: Dicunt ei: Quia nemo nos conduxit. Dicit illis: Ite et vos in vineam meam.

verses.textEn: And when evening had arrived, the lord of the vineyard said to his manager, ‘Call the workers and pay them their wages, beginning from the last, even to the first.’
verses.textLa: Cum sero autem factum esset, dicit dominus vineæ procuratori suo: Voca operarios, et redde illis mercedem incipiens a novissimis usque ad primos.

verses.textEn: And so, when those who had arrived about the eleventh hour came forward, each received a single denarius.
verses.textLa: Cum venissent ergo qui circa undecimam horam venerant, acceperunt singulos denarios.

verses.textEn: Then when the first ones also came forward, they considered that they would receive more. But they, too, received one denarius.
verses.textLa: Venientes autem et primi, arbitrati sunt quod plus essent accepturi: acceperunt autem et ipsi singulos denarios.

verses.textEn: And upon receiving it, they murmured against the father of the family,
verses.textLa: Et accipientes murmurabant adversus patremfamilias,

verses.textEn: saying, ‘These last have worked for one hour, and you have made them equal to us, who worked bearing the weight and heat of the day.’
verses.textLa: dicentes: Hi novissimi una hora fecerunt, et pares illos nobis fecisti, qui portavimus pondus diei, et æstus.

verses.textEn: But responding to one of them, he said: ‘Friend, I caused you no injury. Did you not agree with me to one denarius?
verses.textLa: At ille respondens uni eorum, dixit: Amice non facio tibi iniuriam: nonne ex denario convenisti mecum?

verses.textEn: Take what is yours and go. But it is my will to give to this last, just as to you.
verses.textLa: Tolle quod tuum est, et vade: volo autem et huic novissimo dare sicut et tibi.

verses.textEn: And is it not lawful for me to do what I will? Or is your eye wicked because I am good?’
verses.textLa: Aut non licet mihi quod volo, facere? An oculus tuus nequam est, quia ego bonus sum?

verses.textEn: So then, the last shall be first, and the first shall be last. For many are called, but few are chosen.”
verses.textLa: Sic erunt novissimi primi, et primi novissimi. Multi enim sunt vocati, pauci vero electi.
verses.notes: Or: “For the called are many, yet truly, the elect are few.”

verses.textEn: And Jesus, ascending to Jerusalem, took the twelve disciples aside in private and said to them:
verses.textLa: Et ascendens Iesus Ierosolymam, assumpsit duodecim discipulos secreto, et ait illis:

verses.textEn: “Behold, we are ascending to Jerusalem, and the Son of man shall be handed over to the leaders of the priests and to the scribes. And they shall condemn him to death.
verses.textLa: Ecce ascendimus Ierosolymam, et Filius hominis tradetur principibus sacerdotum, et Scribis, et condemnabunt eum morte,

verses.textEn: And they shall hand him over to the Gentiles to be mocked and scourged and crucified. And on the third day, he shall rise again.”
verses.textLa: et tradent eum Gentibus ad illudendum, et flagellandum, et crucifigendum, et tertia die resurget.

verses.textEn: Then the mother of the sons of Zebedee approached him, with her sons, adoring him, and petitioning something from him.
verses.textLa: Tunc accessit ad eum mater filiorum Zebedæi cum filiis suis, adorans et petens aliquid ab eo.

verses.textEn: And he said to her, “What do you want?” She said to him, “Declare that these, my two sons, may sit, one at your right hand, and the other at your left, in your kingdom.”
verses.textLa: Qui dixit ei: Quid vis? Ait illi: Dic ut sedeant hi duo filii mei, unus ad dexteram tuam, et unus ad sinistram in regno tuo.

verses.textEn: But Jesus, responding, said: “You do not know what you are asking. Are you able to drink from the chalice, from which I will drink?” They said to him, “We are able.”
verses.textLa: Respondens autem Iesus, dixit: Nescitis quid petatis. Potestis bibere calicem, quem ego bibiturus sum? Dicunt ei: Possumus.

verses.textEn: He said to them: “From my chalice, indeed, you shall drink. But to sit at my right or my left is not mine to give to you, but it is for those for whom it has been prepared by my Father.”
verses.textLa: Ait illis: Calicem quidem meum bibetis: sedere autem ad dexteram meam vel sinistram non est meum dare vobis, sed quibus paratum est a Patre meo.

verses.textEn: And the ten, upon hearing this, became indignant with the two brothers.
verses.textLa: Et audientes decem, indignati sunt de duobus fratribus.

verses.textEn: But Jesus called them to himself and said: “You know that the first ones among the Gentiles are their rulers, and that those who are greater exercise power among them.
verses.textLa: Iesus autem vocavit eos ad se, et ait: Scitis quia principes Gentium dominantur eorum: et qui maiores sunt, potestatem exercent in eos.

verses.textEn: It shall not be this way among you. But whoever will want to be greater among you, let him be your minister.
verses.textLa: Non ita erit inter vos: sed quicumque voluerit inter vos maior fieri, sit vester minister:

verses.textEn: And whoever will want to be first among you, he shall be your servant,
verses.textLa: et qui voluerit inter vos primus esse, erit vester servus.

verses.textEn: even as the Son of man has not come to be served, but to serve, and to give his life as a redemption for many.”
verses.textLa: Sicut Filius hominis non venit ministrari, sed ministrare, et dare animam suam, redemptionem pro multis.

verses.textEn: And as they were departing from Jericho, a great crowd followed him.
verses.textLa: Et egredientibus illis ab Iericho, secuta est eum turba multa,

verses.textEn: And behold, two blind men, sitting by the way, heard that Jesus was passing by; and they cried out, saying, “Lord, Son of David, take pity on us.”
verses.textLa: et ecce duo cæci sedentes secus viam, audierunt, quia Iesus transiret: et clamaverunt, dicentes: Domine miserere nostri, fili David.

verses.textEn: But the crowd rebuked them to be quiet. But they cried out all the more, saying, “Lord, Son of David, take pity on us.”
verses.textLa: Turba autem increpabat eos ut tacerent. At illi magis clamabant, dicentes: Domine, miserere nostri, fili David.

verses.textEn: And Jesus stood still, and he called them and said, “What do you want, that I might do for you?”
verses.textLa: Et stetit Iesus, et vocavit eos, et ait: Quid vultis ut faciam vobis?

verses.textEn: They said to him, “Lord, that our eyes be opened.”
verses.textLa: Dicunt illi: Domine, ut aperiantur oculi nostri.

verses.textEn: Then Jesus, taking pity on them, touched their eyes. And immediately they saw, and they followed him.
verses.textLa: Misertus autem eorum Iesus, tetigit oculos eorum. Et confestim viderunt, et secuti sunt eum.

verses.textEn: And when they had drawn near to Jerusalem, and had arrived at Bethphage, at the Mount of Olives, then Jesus sent two disciples,
verses.textLa: Et cum appropinquassent Ierosolymis, et venissent Bethphage ad Montem Oliveti: tunc Iesus misit duos discipulos,
verses.notes: Or, the Mount of Olive Gardens.

verses.textEn: saying to them: “Go into the town that is opposite you, and immediately you will find a donkey tied, and a colt with her. Release them, and lead them to me.
verses.textLa: dicens eis: Ite in castellum, quod contra vos est, et statim invenietis asinam alligatam, et pullum cum ea: solvite, et adducite mihi:

verses.textEn: And if anyone will have said anything to you, say that the Lord has need of them. And he will promptly dismiss them.”
verses.textLa: et si quis vobis aliquid dixerit, dicite quia Dominus his opus habet: et confestim dimittet eos.

verses.textEn: Now all this was done in order to fulfill what was spoken through the prophet, saying,
verses.textLa: Hoc autem totum factum est, ut adimpleretur quod dictum est per prophetam, dicentem:

verses.textEn: “Tell the daughter of Zion: Behold, your king comes to you meekly, sitting on a donkey and on a colt, the son of one accustomed to the yoke.”
verses.textLa: Dicite filiæ Sion: Ecce Rex tuus venit tibi mansuetus, sedens super asinam, et pullum filium subiugalis.

verses.textEn: Then the disciples, going out, did just as Jesus instructed them.
verses.textLa: Euntes autem discipuli fecerunt sicut præcepit illis Iesus.

verses.textEn: And they brought the donkey and the colt, and they laid their garments on them, and they helped him sit upon them.
verses.textLa: Et adduxerunt asinam, et pullum: et imposuerunt super eos vestimenta sua, et eum desuper sedere fecerunt.

verses.textEn: Then a very numerous crowd spread their garments on the way. But others cut branches from the trees and scattered them on the way.
verses.textLa: Plurima autem turba straverunt vestimenta sua in via: alii autem cædebant ramos de arboribus, et sternebant in via:

verses.textEn: And the crowds that preceded him, and those that followed, cried out, saying: “Hosanna to the Son of David! Blessed is he who comes in the name of the Lord. Hosanna in the highest!”
verses.textLa: turbæ autem, quæ præcedebant, et quæ sequebantur, clamabant, dicentes: Hosanna Filio David: benedictus, qui venit in nomine Domini: hosanna in altissimis.

verses.textEn: And when he had entered into Jerusalem, the entire city was stirred up, saying, “Who is this?”
verses.textLa: Et cum intrasset Ierosolymam, commota est universa civitas, dicens: Quis est hic?

verses.textEn: But the people were saying, “This is Jesus, the Prophet from Nazareth of Galilee.”
verses.textLa: Populi autem dicebant: Hic est Iesus Propheta a Nazareth Galilææ.

verses.textEn: And Jesus entered into the temple of God, and he cast out all who were selling and buying in the temple, and he overturned the tables of the money changers and the chairs of the vendors of doves.
verses.textLa: Et intravit Iesus in templum Dei, et eiiciebat omnes vendentes, et ementes in templo, et mensas numulariorum, et cathedras vendentium columbas evertit:

verses.textEn: And he said to them: “It is written: ‘My house shall be called a house of prayer. But you have made it into a den of robbers.’ ”
verses.textLa: et dicit eis: Scriptum est: Domus mea domus orationis vocabitur: vos autem fecistis illam speluncam latronum.
verses.notes: The Jewish Law distinguishes between theft and robbery; the former involves secretive stealing, the latter involves stealing directly from someone, using force. The word ‘latronum’ refers to robbery, not theft.

verses.textEn: And the blind and the lame drew near to him in the temple; and he healed them.
verses.textLa: Et accesserunt ad eum cæci, et claudi in templo: et sanavit eos.

verses.textEn: Then the leaders of the priests and the scribes became indignant, seeing the miracles that he wrought, and the children crying out in the temple, saying, “Hosanna to the Son of David!”
verses.textLa: Videntes autem principes sacerdotum, et Scribæ mirabilia, quæ fecit, et pueros clamantes in templo, et dicentes: Hosanna Filio David: indignati sunt,

verses.textEn: And they said to him, “Do you hear what these ones are saying?” But Jesus said to them, “Certainly. Have you never read: For out of the mouth of babes and infants, you have perfected praise?”
verses.textLa: et dixerunt ei: Audis quid isti dicunt? Iesus autem dixit eis: Utique. Numquam legistis: Quia ex ore infantium, et lactentium perfecisti laudem?

verses.textEn: And leaving them behind, he went out, beyond the city, into Bethania, and he lodged here.
verses.textLa: Et relictis illis, abiit foras extra Civitatem in Bethaniam: ibique mansit.

verses.textEn: Then, as he was returning to the city in the morning, he was hungry.
verses.textLa: Mane autem revertens in Civitatem, esuriit.

verses.textEn: And seeing a certain fig tree beside the way, he approached it. And he found nothing on it, except only leaves. And he said to it, “May fruit never spring forth from you, for all time.” And immediately the fig tree was dried up.
verses.textLa: Et videns fici arborem unam secus viam, venit ad eam: et nihil invenit in ea nisi folia tantum, et ait illi: Numquam ex te fructus nascatur in sempiternum. Et arefacta est continuo ficulnea.

verses.textEn: And seeing this, the disciples wondered, saying, “How did it dry up so quickly?”
verses.textLa: Et videntes discipuli, mirati sunt, dicentes: Quomodo continuo aruit?

verses.textEn: And Jesus responded to them by saying: “Amen I say to you, if you have faith and do not hesitate, not only shall you do this, concerning the fig tree, but even if you would say to this mountain, ‘Take and cast yourself into the sea,’ it shall be done.
verses.textLa: Respondens autem Iesus, ait eis: Amen dico vobis, si habueritis fidem, et non hæsitaveritis, non solum de ficulnea facietis, sed et si monti huic dixeritis, Tolle, et iacta te in mare, fiet.

verses.textEn: And all things whatsoever that you shall ask for in prayer: believing, you shall receive.”
verses.textLa: Et omnia quæcumque petieritis in oratione credentes, accipietis.

verses.textEn: And when he had arrived at the temple, as he was teaching, the leaders of the priests and the elders of the people approached him, saying: “By what authority do you do these things? And who has given this authority to you?”
verses.textLa: Et cum venisset in templum, accesserunt ad eum docentem, principes sacerdotum, et seniores populi, dicentes: In qua potestate hæc facis? Et quis tibi dedit hanc potestatem?

verses.textEn: In response, Jesus said to them: “I also will question you with one word: if you tell me this, I also will tell you by what authority I do these things.
verses.textLa: Respondens Iesus dixit eis: Interrogabo vos et ego unum sermonem: quem si dixeritis mihi, et ego vobis dicam in qua potestate hæc facio.

verses.textEn: The baptism of John, where was it from? Was it from heaven, or from men?” But they thought within themselves, saying:
verses.textLa: Baptismus Ioannis unde erat? e cælo, an ex hominibus? At illi cogitabant inter se, dicentes:

verses.textEn: “If we say, ‘From heaven,’ he will say to us, ‘Then why did you not believe him?’ But if we say, ‘From men,’ we have the crowd to fear, for they all hold John to be a prophet.”
verses.textLa: Si dixerimus, e cælo, dicet nobis: Quare ergo non credidistis illi? Si autem dixerimus, ex hominibus, timemus turbam: omnes enim habebant Ioannem sicut prophetam.

verses.textEn: And so, they answered Jesus by saying, “We do not know.” So he also said to them: “Neither will I tell you by what authority I do these things.
verses.textLa: Et respondentes Iesu, dixerunt: Nescimus. Ait illis et ipse: Nec ego dico vobis in qua potestate hæc facio.

verses.textEn: But how does it seem to you? A certain man had two sons. And approaching the first, he said: ‘Son, go out today to work in my vineyard.’
verses.textLa: Quid autem vobis videtur? Homo quidam habebat duos filios, et accedens ad primum, dixit: Fili, vade hodie, operare in vinea mea.

verses.textEn: And responding, he said, ‘I am not willing.’ But afterwards, being moved by repentance, he went.
verses.textLa: Ille autem respondens, ait: Nolo. Postea autem, pœnitentia motus, abiit.

verses.textEn: And approaching the other, he spoke similarly. And answering, he said, ‘I am going, lord.’ And he did not go.
verses.textLa: Accedens autem ad alterum, dixit similiter. At ille respondens, ait: Eo, domine, et non ivit.

verses.textEn: Which of the two did the will of the father?” They said to him, “The first.” Jesus said to them: “Amen I say to you, that tax collectors and prostitutes shall precede you, into the kingdom of God.
verses.textLa: Quis ex duobus fecit voluntatem patris? Dicunt ei: Primus. Dicit illis Iesus: Amen dico vobis, quia publicani, et meretrices præcedent vos in regnum Dei.
verses.notes: The word ‘meretrices’ can also refer to loose or promiscuous women.

verses.textEn: For John came to you in the way of justice, and you did not believe him. But the tax collectors and the prostitutes believed him. Yet even after seeing this, you did not repent, so as to believe him.
verses.textLa: Venit enim ad vos Ioannes in via iustitiæ, et non credidistis ei. Publicani autem, et meretrices crediderunt ei: vos autem videntes nec pœnitentiam habuistis postea, ut crederetis ei.

verses.textEn: Listen to another parable. There was a man, the father of a family, who planted a vineyard, and surrounded it with a hedge, and dug a press in it, and built a tower. And he loaned it out to farmers, and he set out to sojourn abroad.
verses.textLa: Aliam parabolam audite: Homo erat paterfamilias, qui plantavit vineam, et sepem circumdedit ei, et fodit in ea torcular, et ædificavit turrim, et locavit eam agricolis, et peregre profectus est.

verses.textEn: Then, when the time of the fruits drew near, he sent his servants to the farmers, so that they might receive its fruits.
verses.textLa: Cum autem tempus fructuum appropinquasset, misit servos suos ad agricolas, ut acciperent fructus eius.

verses.textEn: And the farmers apprehended his servants; they struck one, and killed another, and stoned yet another.
verses.textLa: Et agricolæ, apprehensis servis eius, alium ceciderunt, alium occiderunt, alium vero lapidaverunt.

verses.textEn: Again, he sent other servants, more than before; and they treated them similarly.
verses.textLa: Iterum misit alios servos plures prioribus, et fecerunt illis similiter.

verses.textEn: Then, at the very end, he sent his son to them, saying: ‘They will revere my son.’
verses.textLa: Novissime autem misit ad eos filium suum, dicens: Verebuntur filium meum.

verses.textEn: But the farmers, seeing the son, said among themselves: ‘This is the heir. Come, let us kill him, and then we will have his inheritance.’
verses.textLa: Agricolæ autem videntes filium, dixerunt intra se: Hic est hæres, venite, occidamus eum, et habebimus hereditatem eius.

verses.textEn: And apprehending him, they cast him outside the vineyard, and they killed him.
verses.textLa: Et apprehensum eum eiecerunt extra vineam, et occiderunt.
verses.notes: Christ was killed just outside Jerusalem, the holy city.

verses.textEn: Therefore, when the lord of the vineyard arrives, what will he do to those farmers?”
verses.textLa: Cum ergo venerit dominus vineæ, quid faciet agricolis illis?

verses.textEn: They said to him, “He will bring those evil men to an evil end, and he will loan out his vineyard to other farmers, who shall repay to him the fruit in its time.”
verses.textLa: Aiunt illi: Malos male perdet: et vineam suam locabit aliis agricolis, qui reddant ei fructum temporibus suis.

verses.textEn: Jesus said to them: “Have you never read in the Scriptures: ‘The stone that the builders have rejected has become the cornerstone. By the Lord has this been done, and it is wonderful in our eyes?’
verses.textLa: Dicit illis Iesus: Numquam legistis in Scripturis: Lapidem, quem reprobaverunt ædificantes, hic factus est in caput anguli. A Domino factum est istud, et est mirabile in oculis nostris:
verses.notes: The question mark is omitted because the quote from Scripture is not a question and because it is a rhetorical question.

verses.textEn: Therefore, I say to you, that the kingdom of God will be taken away from you, and it shall be given to a people who shall produce its fruits.
verses.textLa: ideo dico vobis, quia auferetur a vobis regnum Dei, et dabitur genti facienti fructus eius.

verses.textEn: And whoever will have fallen on this stone shall be broken, yet truly, on whomever it shall fall, it will crush him.”
verses.textLa: Et qui ceciderit super lapidem istum, confringetur: super quem vero ceciderit, conteret eum.

verses.textEn: And when the leaders of the priests, and the Pharisees had heard his parables, they knew that he was speaking about them.
verses.textLa: Et cum audissent principes sacerdotum, et Pharisæi parabolas eius, cognoverunt quod de ipsis diceret.

verses.textEn: And though they sought to take hold of him, they feared the crowds, because they held him to be a prophet.
verses.textLa: Et quærentes eum tenere, timuerunt turbas: quoniam sicut prophetam eum habebant.
verses.notes: Or, ‘the Prophet’ (the one predicted to be greater than Moses).

verses.textEn: And responding, Jesus again spoke to them in parables, saying:
verses.textLa: Et respondens Iesus, dixit iterum in parabolis eis, dicens:

verses.textEn: “The kingdom of heaven is like a man who was king, who celebrated a wedding for his son.
verses.textLa: Simile factum est regnum cælorum homini regi, qui fecit nuptias filio suo.

verses.textEn: And he sent his servants to call those who were invited to the wedding. But they were not willing to come.
verses.textLa: Et misit servos suos vocare invitatos ad nuptias, et nolebant venire.

verses.textEn: Again, he sent other servants, saying, ‘Tell the invited: Behold, I have prepared my meal. My bulls and fatlings have been killed, and all is ready. Come to the wedding.’
verses.textLa: Iterum misit alios servos, dicens: Dicite invitatis: Ecce prandium meum paravi, tauri mei, et altilia occisa sunt, et omnia parata: venite ad nuptias.

verses.textEn: But they ignored this and they went away: one to his country estate, and another to his business.
verses.textLa: Illi autem neglexerunt: et abierunt, alius in villam suam, alius vero ad negotiationem suam:

verses.textEn: Yet truly, the rest took hold of his servants and, having treated them with contempt, killed them.
verses.textLa: reliqui vero tenuerunt servos eius, et contumeliis affectos occiderunt.

verses.textEn: But when the king heard this, he was angry. And sending out his armies, he destroyed those murderers, and he burned their city.
verses.textLa: Rex autem cum audisset, iratus est: et missis exercitibus suis, perdidit homicidas illos, et civitatem illorum succendit.

verses.textEn: Then he said to his servants: ‘The wedding, indeed, has been prepared. But those who were invited were not worthy.
verses.textLa: Tunc ait servis suis: Nuptiæ quidem paratæ sunt, sed qui invitati erant, non fuerunt digni.

verses.textEn: Therefore, go out to the ways, and call whomever you will find to the wedding.’
verses.textLa: Ite ergo ad exitus viarum, et quoscumque inveneritis, vocate ad nuptias.

verses.textEn: And his servants, departing into the ways, gathered all those whom they found, bad and good, and the wedding was filled with guests.
verses.textLa: Et egressi servi eius in vias, congregaverunt omnes, quos invenerunt, malos et bonos: et impletæ sunt nuptiæ discumbentium.

verses.textEn: Then the king entered to see the guests. And he saw a man there who was not clothed in a wedding garment.
verses.textLa: Intravit autem rex ut viderent discumbentes, et vidit ibi hominem non vestitum veste nuptiali.

verses.textEn: And he said to him, ‘Friend, how is it that you have entered here without having a wedding garment?’ But he was dumbstruck.
verses.textLa: Et ait illi: Amice, quomodo huc intrasti non habens vestem nuptialem? At ille obmutuit.

verses.textEn: Then the king said to the ministers: ‘Bind his hands and feet, and cast him into the outer darkness, where there will be weeping and gnashing of teeth.
verses.textLa: Tunc dicit rex ministris: Ligatis manibus, et pedibus eius, mittite eum in tenebras exteriores: ibi erit fletus, et stridor dentium.

verses.textEn: For many are called, but few are chosen.’ ”
verses.textLa: Multi enim sunt vocati, pauci vero electi.

verses.textEn: Then the Pharisees, going out, took counsel as to how they might entrap him in speech.
verses.textLa: Tunc abeuntes Pharisæi, consilium inierunt ut caperent eum in sermone.

verses.textEn: And they sent their disciples to him, with the Herodians, saying: “Teacher, we know that you are truthful, and that you teach the way of God in truth, and that the influence of others is nothing to you. For you do not consider the reputation of men.
verses.textLa: Et mittunt ei discipulos suos cum Herodianis dicentes: Magister, scimus quia verax es, et viam Dei in veritate doces, et non est tibi cura de aliquo: non enim respicis personam hominum:

verses.textEn: Therefore, tell us, how does it seem to you? Is it lawful to pay the census tax to Caesar, or not?”
verses.textLa: dic ergo nobis quid tibi videtur? licet censum dare Cæsari, an non?

verses.textEn: But Jesus, knowing their wickedness, said: “Why do you test me, you hypocrites?
verses.textLa: Cognita autem Iesus nequitia eorum, ait: Quid me tentatis hypocritæ?

verses.textEn: Show me the coin of the census tax.” And they offered him a denarius.
verses.textLa: Ostendite mihi numisma census. At illi obtulerunt ei denarium.

verses.textEn: And Jesus said to them, “Whose image is this, and whose inscription?”
verses.textLa: Et ait illis Iesus: Cuius est imago hæc, et superscriptio?

verses.textEn: They said to him, “Caesar’s.” Then he said to them, “Then render to Caesar what is of Caesar; and to God what is of God.”
verses.textLa: Dicunt ei: Cæsaris. Tunc ait illis: Reddite ergo quæ sunt Cæsaris, Cæsari: et quæ sunt Dei, Deo.

verses.textEn: And hearing this, they wondered. And having left him behind, they went away.
verses.textLa: Et audientes mirati sunt, et relicto eo abierunt.

verses.textEn: In that day, the Sadducees, who say there is to be no resurrection, approached him. And they questioned him,
verses.textLa: In illo die accesserunt ad eum Sadducæi, qui dicunt non esse resurrectionem: et interrogaverunt eum,
verses.notes: The phrase “On that day” could also be translated as “In that day,” such that the expression would not indicate the same day, but the same general time frame.

verses.textEn: saying: “Teacher, Moses said: If anyone will have died, having no son, his brother shall marry his wife, and he shall raise up offspring to his brother.
verses.textLa: dicentes: Magister, Moyses dixit: Si quis mortuus fuerit non habens filium, ut ducat frater eius uxorem illius, et suscitet semen fratri suo.

verses.textEn: Now there were seven brothers with us. And the first, having taken a wife, died. And having no offspring, he left his wife to his brother:
verses.textLa: Erant autem apud nos septem fratres: et primus, uxore ducta, defunctus est: et non habens semen, reliquit uxorem suam fratri suo.

verses.textEn: similarly with the second, and the third, even to the seventh.
verses.textLa: Similiter secundus, et tertius usque ad septimum.

verses.textEn: And last of all, the woman also passed away.
verses.textLa: Novissime autem omnium et mulier defuncta est.

verses.textEn: In the resurrection, then, whose wife of the seven will she be? For they all had her.”
verses.textLa: In resurrectione ergo cuius erit de septem uxor? omnes enim habuerunt eam.

verses.textEn: But Jesus responded to them by saying: “You have gone astray by knowing neither the Scriptures, nor the power of God.
verses.textLa: Respondens autem Iesus, ait illis: Erratis nescientes Scripturas, neque virtutem Dei.

verses.textEn: For in the resurrection, they shall neither marry, nor be given in marriage. Instead, they shall be like the Angels of God in heaven.
verses.textLa: In resurrectione enim neque nubent, neque nubentur: sed erunt sicut Angeli Dei in cælo.

verses.textEn: But concerning the resurrection of the dead, have you not read what was spoken by God, saying to you:
verses.textLa: De resurrectione autem mortuorum non legistis quod dictum est a Deo dicente vobis:

verses.textEn: ‘I am the God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob?’ He is not the God of the dead, but of the living.”
verses.textLa: Ego sum Deus Abraham, et Deus Isaac, et Deus Iacob? Non est Deus mortuorum, sed viventium.
verses.notes: This formula, which mentions God three times in one definition of who God is, refers also to the mystery of the Trinity.

verses.textEn: And when the crowds heard this, they wondered at his doctrine.
verses.textLa: Et audientes turbæ, mirabantur in doctrina eius.

verses.textEn: But the Pharisees, hearing that he had caused the Sadducees to be silent, came together as one.
verses.textLa: Pharisæi autem audientes quod silentium imposuisset Sadducæis, convenerunt in unum:

verses.textEn: And one of them, a doctor of the law, questioned him, to test him:
verses.textLa: et interrogavit eum unus ex eis legis doctor, tentans eum:

verses.textEn: “Teacher, which is the great commandment in the law?”
verses.textLa: Magister, quod est mandatum magnum in lege?

verses.textEn: Jesus said to him: “ ‘You shall love the Lord your God from all your heart, and with all your soul and with all your mind.’
verses.textLa: Ait illi Iesus: Diliges Dominum Deum tuum ex toto corde tuo, et in tota anima tua, et in tota mente tua.

verses.textEn: This is the greatest and first commandment.
verses.textLa: Hoc est maximum, et primum mandatum.

verses.textEn: But the second is similar to it: ‘You shall love your neighbor as yourself.’
verses.textLa: Secundum autem simile est huic: Diliges proximum tuum, sicut teipsum.

verses.textEn: On these two commandments the entire law depends, and also the prophets.”
verses.textLa: In his duobus mandatis universa lex pendet, et prophetæ.

verses.textEn: Then, when the Pharisees were gathered together, Jesus questioned them,
verses.textLa: Congregatis autem Pharisæis, interrogavit eos Iesus,

verses.textEn: saying: “What do you think about the Christ? Whose son is he?” They said to him, “David’s.”
verses.textLa: dicens: Quid vobis videtur de Christo? cuius filius est? Dicunt ei: David.

verses.textEn: He said to them: “Then how can David, in the Spirit, call him Lord, saying:
verses.textLa: Ait illis: Quomodo ergo David in Spiritu vocat eum Dominum, dicens:

verses.textEn: ‘The Lord said to my Lord: Sit at my right hand, until I make your enemies your footstool?’
verses.textLa: Dixit Dominus Domino meo: sede a dextris meis, donec ponam inimicos tuos scabellum pedum tuorum?

verses.textEn: So then, if David calls him Lord, how can he be his son?”
verses.textLa: Si ergo David vocat eum Dominum, quomodo filius eius est?

verses.textEn: And no one was able to respond to him a word. And neither did anyone dare, from that day forward, to question him.
verses.textLa: Et nemo poterat ei respondere verbum: neque ausus fuit quisquam ex illa die eum amplius interrogare.

verses.textEn: Then Jesus spoke to the crowds, and to his disciples,
verses.textLa: Tunc Iesus locutus est ad turbas, et ad discipulos suos,

verses.textEn: saying: “The scribes and the Pharisees have sat down in the chair of Moses.
verses.textLa: dicens: Super cathedram Moysi sederunt Scribæ, et Pharisæi.

verses.textEn: Therefore, all things whatsoever that they shall say to you, observe and do. Yet truly, do not choose to act according to their works. For they say, but they do not do.
verses.textLa: Omnia ergo quæcumque dixerint vobis, servate, et facite: secundum opera vero eorum nolite facere: dicunt enim, et non faciunt.

verses.textEn: For they bind up heavy and unbearable burdens, and they impose them on men’s shoulders. But they are not willing to move them with even a finger of their own.
verses.textLa: Alligant enim onera gravia, et importabilia, et imponunt in humeros hominum: digito autem suo nolunt ea movere.

verses.textEn: Truly, they do all their works so that they may be seen by men. For they enlarge their phylacteries and glorify their hems.
verses.textLa: Omnia vero opera sua faciunt ut videantur ab hominibus: dilatant enim phylacteria sua, et magnificant fimbrias.

verses.textEn: And they love the first places at feasts, and the first chairs in the synagogues,
verses.textLa: Amant autem primos recubitus in cœnis, et primas cathedras in synagogis,

verses.textEn: and greetings in the marketplace, and to be called Master by men.
verses.textLa: et salutationes in foro, et vocari ab hominibus Rabbi.

verses.textEn: But you must not be called Master. For One is your Master, and you are all brothers.
verses.textLa: Vos autem nolite vocari Rabbi. Unus est enim Magister vester, omnes autem vos fratres estis.

verses.textEn: And do not choose to call anyone on earth your father. For One is your Father, who is in heaven.
verses.textLa: Et patrem nolite vocare vobis super terram: unus est enim Pater vester, qui in cælis est.

verses.textEn: Neither should you be called teachers. For One is your Teacher, the Christ.
verses.textLa: Nec vocemini magistri: quia Magister vester unus est, Christus.
verses.notes: This passage refers to the Trinity, with the First Person as Father, the Second Person as Teacher (the Christ), and the Third Person as Master (or Leader or Guide).

verses.textEn: Whoever is greater among you shall be your minister.
verses.textLa: Qui maior est vestrum, erit minister vester.

verses.textEn: But whoever has exalted himself, shall be humbled. And whoever has humbled himself, shall be exalted.
verses.textLa: Qui autem se exaltaverit, humiliabitur: et qui se humiliaverit, exaltabitur.

verses.textEn: So then: Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, you hypocrites! For you close the kingdom of heaven before men. For you yourselves do not enter, and those who are entering, you would not permit to enter.
verses.textLa: Væ autem vobis Scribæ, et Pharisæi hypocritæ: quia clauditis regnum cælorum ante homines. Vos enim non intratis, nec introeuntes sinitis intrare.

verses.textEn: Woe to you scribes and Pharisees, you hypocrites! For you consume the houses of widows, praying long prayers. Because of this, you shall receive the greater judgment.
verses.textLa: Væ vobis Scribæ, et Pharisæi hypocritæ: quia comeditis domos viduarum, orationes longas orantes: propter hoc amplius accipietis iudicium.

verses.textEn: Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, you hypocrites! For you travel around by sea and by land, in order to make one convert. And when he has been converted, you make him twice the son of Hell that you are yourselves.
verses.textLa: Væ vobis Scribæ, et Pharisæi hypocritæ: quia circuitis mare, et aridam, ut faciatis unum proselytum: et cum fuerit factus, facitis eum filium Gehennæ duplo quam vos.

verses.textEn: Woe to you, blind guides, who say: ‘Whoever will have sworn by the temple, it is nothing. But whoever will have sworn by the gold of the temple is obligated.’
verses.textLa: Væ vobis duces cæci, qui dicitis: Quicumque iuraverit per templum, nihil est: qui autem iuraverit in auro templi, debet.

verses.textEn: You are foolish and blind! For which is greater: the gold, or the temple that sanctifies the gold?
verses.textLa: Stulti et cæci: Quid enim maius est, aurum, an templum, quod sanctificat aurum?

verses.textEn: And you say: ‘Whoever will have sworn by the altar, it is nothing. But whoever will have sworn by the gift that is on the altar is obligated.’
verses.textLa: Et quicumque iuraverit in altari, nihil est: quicumque autem iuraverit in dono, quod est super illud, debet.

verses.textEn: How blind you are! For which is greater: the gift, or the altar that sanctifies the gift?
verses.textLa: Cæci: quid enim maius est, donum, an altare, quod sanctificat donum?

verses.textEn: Therefore, whoever swears by the altar, swears by it, and by all that is on it.
verses.textLa: Qui ergo iurat in altari, iurat in eo, et in omnibus quæ super illud sunt.

verses.textEn: And whoever will have sworn by the temple, swears by it, and by him who dwells in it.
verses.textLa: Et quicumque iuraverit in templo, iurat in illo, et in eo, qui habitat in ipso:

verses.textEn: And whoever swears by heaven, swears by the throne of God, and by him who sits upon it.
verses.textLa: et qui iurat in cælo, iurat in throno Dei, et in eo, qui sedet super eum.

verses.textEn: Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, you hypocrites! For you collect tithes on mint and dill and cumin, but you have abandoned the weightier things of the law: judgment and mercy and faith. These you ought to have done, while not omitting the others.
verses.textLa: Væ vobis Scribæ, et Pharisæi hypocritæ: qui decimatis mentham, et anethum, et cyminum, et reliquistis quæ graviora sunt legis, iudicium, et misericordiam, et fidem. Hæc oportuit facere, et illa non omittere.

verses.textEn: You blind guides, straining out a gnat, while swallowing a camel!
verses.textLa: Duces cæci, excolantes culicem, camelum autem glutientes.

verses.textEn: Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, you hypocrites! For you clean what is outside the cup and the dish, but on the inside you are full of avarice and impurity.
verses.textLa: Væ vobis Scribæ, et Pharisæi hypocritæ, quia mundatis quod deforis est calicis, et paropsidis: intus autem pleni estis rapina, et immunditia.

verses.textEn: You blind Pharisee! First clean the inside of the cup and the dish, and then what is outside becomes clean.
verses.textLa: Pharisæe cæce, munda prius quod intus est calicis, et paropsidis, ut fiat id, quod deforis est, mundum.

verses.textEn: Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, you hypocrites! For you are like whitewashed sepulchers, which outwardly appear brilliant to men, yet truly, inside, they are filled with the bones of the dead and with all filth.
verses.textLa: Væ vobis Scribæ, et Pharisæi hypocritæ: quia similes estis sepulchris dealbatis, quæ aforis parent hominibus speciosa, intus vero pleni sunt ossibus mortuorum, et omni spurcitia.

verses.textEn: So also, you certainly appear to men outwardly to be just. But inwardly you are filled with hypocrisy and iniquity.
verses.textLa: Sic et vos aforis quidem paretis hominibus iusti: intus autem pleni estis hypocrisi, et iniquitate.

verses.textEn: Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, you hypocrites, who build the sepulchers of the prophets and adorn the monuments of the just.
verses.textLa: Væ vobis Scribæ, et Pharisæi hypocritæ, qui ædificatis sepulchra prophetarum, et ornatis monumenta iustorum,

verses.textEn: And then you say, ‘If we had been there in the days of our fathers, we would not have joined with them in the blood of the prophets.’
verses.textLa: et dicitis: Si fuissemus in diebus patrum nostrorum, non essemus socii eorum in sanguine prophetarum.

verses.textEn: And so you are witnesses against yourselves, that you are the sons of those who killed the prophets.
verses.textLa: Itaque testimonio estis vobismetipsis, quia filii estis eorum, qui prophetas occiderunt.

verses.textEn: Complete, then, the measure of your fathers.
verses.textLa: Et vos implete mensuram patrum vestrorum.

verses.textEn: You serpents, you brood of vipers! How will you escape from the judgment of Hell?
verses.textLa: Serpentes genimina viperarum, quomodo fugietis a iudicio Gehennæ?

verses.textEn: For this reason, behold, I send to you prophets and wise men, and scribes. And some of these you will put to death and crucify; and some you will scourge in your synagogues and persecute from city to city,
verses.textLa: Ideo ecce ego mitto ad vos prophetas, et sapientes, et scribas, et ex illis occidetis, et crucifigetis, et ex eis flagellabitis in synagogis vestris, et persequemini de civitate in civitatem:

verses.textEn: so that upon you may fall all the blood of the just, which has been shed upon the earth, from the blood of Abel the just, even to the blood of Zechariah the son of Barachiah, whom you killed between the temple and the altar.
verses.textLa: ut veniat super vos omnis sanguis iustus, qui effusus est super terram, a sanguine Abel iusti usque ad sanguinem Zachariæ, filii Barachiæ, quem occidistis inter templum et altare.

verses.textEn: Amen I say to you, all these things shall fall upon this generation.
verses.textLa: Amen dico vobis, venient hæc omnia super generationem istam.

verses.textEn: Jerusalem, Jerusalem! You kill the prophets and stone those who have been sent to you. How often I have wanted to gather your children together, in the way that a hen gathers her young under her wings. But you were not willing!
verses.textLa: Ierusalem, Ierusalem, quæ occidis prophetas, et lapidas eos, qui ad te missi sunt: quoties volui congregare filios tuos, quemadmodum gallina congregat pullos suos sub alas, et noluisti?

verses.textEn: Behold, your house shall be abandoned to you, having been deserted.
verses.textLa: Ecce relinquetur vobis domus vestra deserta.

verses.textEn: For I say to you, you shall not see me again, until you say: ‘Blessed is he who comes in the name of the Lord.’ ”
verses.textLa: Dico enim vobis, non me videbitis amodo, donec dicatis: Benedictus, qui venit in nomine Domini.

verses.textEn: And Jesus departed from the temple and went away. And his disciples approached him, so as to show him the buildings of the temple.
verses.textLa: Et egressus Iesus de templo, ibat. Et accesserunt discipuli eius, ut ostenderent ei ædificationes templi.

verses.textEn: But he said to them in response: “Do you see all these things? Amen I say to you, there shall not remain here stone upon stone, which is not torn down.”
verses.textLa: Ipse autem respondens dixit illis: Videtis hæc omnia? Amen dico vobis, non relinquetur hic lapis super lapidem, qui non destruatur.

verses.textEn: Then, when he was seated at the Mount of Olives, the disciples drew near to him privately, saying: “Tell us, when will these things be? And what will be the sign of your advent and of the consummation of the age?”
verses.textLa: Sedente autem eo super Montem Oliveti, accesserunt ad eum discipuli secreto, dicentes: Dic nobis, quando hæc erunt? et quod signum adventus tui, et consummationis sæculi?

verses.textEn: And answering, Jesus said to them: “Pay attention, lest someone lead you astray.
verses.textLa: Et respondens Iesus, dixit eis: Videte ne quis vos seducat.

verses.textEn: For many will come in my name saying, ‘I am the Christ.’ And they will lead many astray.
verses.textLa: Multi enim venient in nomine meo, dicentes: Ego sum Christus: et multos seducent.

verses.textEn: For you will hear of battles and rumors of battles. Take care not to be disturbed. For these things must be, but the end is not so soon.
verses.textLa: Audituri enim estis prælia, et opiniones præliorum. Videte ne turbemini. Oportet enim hæc fieri, sed nondum est finis.

verses.textEn: For nation will rise against nation, and kingdom against kingdom. And there will be pestilences, and famines, and earthquakes in places.
verses.textLa: Consurget enim gens in gentem, et regnum in regnum, et erunt pestilentiæ, et fames, et terræmotus per loca.

verses.textEn: But all these things are just the beginning of the sorrows.
verses.textLa: Hæc autem omnia initia sunt dolorum.

verses.textEn: Then they will hand you over to tribulation, and they will kill you. And you will be hated by all nations for the sake of my name.
verses.textLa: Tunc tradent vos in tribulationem, et occident vos: et eritis odio omnibus gentibus propter nomen meum.

verses.textEn: And then many will be led into sin, and will betray one another, and will have hatred for one another.
verses.textLa: Et tunc scandalizabuntur multi, et invicem tradent, et odio habebunt invicem.

verses.textEn: And many false prophets will arise, and they will lead many astray.
verses.textLa: Et multi pseudoprophetæ surgent, et seducent multos.

verses.textEn: And because iniquity has abounded, the charity of many will grow cold.
verses.textLa: Et quoniam abundavit iniquitas, refrigescet caritas multorum.

verses.textEn: But whoever will have persevered until the end, the same shall be saved.
verses.textLa: Qui autem perseveraverit usque in finem, hic salvus erit.

verses.textEn: And this Gospel of the kingdom shall be preached throughout the entire world, as a testimony to all nations. And then the consummation will occur.
verses.textLa: Et prædicabitur hoc Evangelium regni in universo orbe, in testimonium omnibus gentibus: et tunc veniet consummatio.

verses.textEn: Therefore, when you will have seen the abomination of desolation, which was spoken of by the prophet Daniel, standing in the holy place, may he who reads understand,
verses.textLa: Cum ergo videritis abominationem desolationis, quæ dicta est a Daniele propheta, stantem in loco sancto, qui legit, intelligat:

verses.textEn: then those who are in Judea, let them flee to the mountains.
verses.textLa: tunc qui in Iudæa sunt, fugiant ad montes:

verses.textEn: And whoever is on the roof, let him not descend to take anything from his house.
verses.textLa: et qui in tecto, non descendat tollere aliquid de domo sua:

verses.textEn: And whoever is in the field, let him not turn back to take his tunic.
verses.textLa: et qui in agro, non revertatur tollere tunicam suam.

verses.textEn: So then, woe to those who are pregnant or nursing in those days.
verses.textLa: Væ autem prægnantibus, et nutrientibus in illis diebus.

verses.textEn: But pray that your flight may not be in winter, or on the Sabbath.
verses.textLa: Orate autem ut non fiat fuga vestra in hieme, vel sabbato.

verses.textEn: For then there will be a great tribulation, such as has not been from the beginning of the world until the present, and such as will not be.
verses.textLa: Erit enim tunc tribulatio magna, qualis non fuit ab initio mundi usque modo, neque fiet.
verses.notes: This verse refers to the greater tribulation, i.e. the second part of the tribulation, not the first, because the first part of the tribulation (the lesser tribulation) will be exceeded in severity by the second part (the greater tribulation).

verses.textEn: And unless those days had been shortened, no flesh would be saved. But for the sake of the elect, those days shall be shortened.
verses.textLa: Et nisi breviati fuissent dies illi, non fieret salva omnis caro: sed propter electos breviabuntur dies illi.

verses.textEn: Then if anyone will have said to you, ‘Behold, here is the Christ,’ or ‘he is there,’ do not be willing to believe it.
verses.textLa: Tunc si quis vobis dixerit: Ecce hic est Christus, aut illic: nolite credere.

verses.textEn: For there will arise false Christs and false prophets. And they will produce great signs and wonders, so much so as to lead into error even the elect (if this could be).
verses.textLa: Surgent enim pseudochristi, et pseudoprophetæ: et dabunt signa magna, et prodigia, ita ut in errorem inducantur (si fieri potest) etiam electi.

verses.textEn: Behold, I have warned you beforehand.
verses.textLa: Ecce prædixi vobis.

verses.textEn: Therefore, if they will have said to you, ‘Behold, he is in the desert,’ do not choose to go out, or, ‘Behold, he is in the inner rooms,’ do not be willing to believe it.
verses.textLa: Si ergo dixerint vobis, Ecce in deserto est, nolite exire: Ecce in penetralibus, nolite credere.

verses.textEn: For just as lightning goes out from the east, and appears even in the west, so shall it be also at the advent of the Son of man.
verses.textLa: Sicut enim fulgur exit ab Oriente, et paret usque in Occidentem: ita erit et adventus Filii hominis.

verses.textEn: Wherever the body shall be, there also will the eagles be gathered together.
verses.textLa: Ubicumque fuerit corpus, illic congregabuntur et aquilæ.

verses.textEn: And immediately after the tribulation of those days, the sun will be darkened, and the moon will not give its light, and the stars will fall from heaven, and the powers of the heavens will be shaken.
verses.textLa: Statim autem post tribulationem dierum illorum sol obscurabitur, et luna non dabit lumen suum, et stellæ cadent de cælo, et virtutes cælorum commovebuntur:

verses.textEn: And then the sign of the Son of man shall appear in heaven. And then all tribes of the earth shall mourn. And they shall see the Son of man coming on the clouds of heaven, with great power and majesty.
verses.textLa: et tunc parebit signum Filii hominis in cælo: et tunc plangent omnes tribus terræ: et videbunt Filium hominis venientem in nubibus cæli cum virtute multa, et maiestate.

verses.textEn: And he shall send out his Angels with a trumpet and a great voice. And they shall gather together his elect from the four winds, from the heights of the heavens, even to their furthest limits.
verses.textLa: Et mittet Angelos suos cum tuba, et voce magna: et congregabunt electos eius a quattuor ventis, a summis cælorum usque ad terminos eorum.

verses.textEn: So, from the fig tree learn a parable. When its branch has now become tender and the leaves have sprung forth, you know that summer is near.
verses.textLa: Ab arbore autem fici discite parabolam: cum iam ramus eius tener fuerit, et folia nata, scitis quia prope est æstas:

verses.textEn: So also, when you will have seen all these things, know that it is near, even at the threshold.
verses.textLa: ita et vos cum videritis hæc omnia, scitote quia prope est in ianuis.

verses.textEn: Amen I say to you, that this lineage shall not pass away, until all these things have been done.
verses.textLa: Amen dico vobis, quia non præteribit generatio hæc, donec omnia hæc fiant.

verses.textEn: Heaven and earth shall pass away, but my words shall not pass away.
verses.textLa: Cælum, et terra transibunt, verba autem mea non præteribunt.

verses.textEn: But concerning that day and hour, no one knows, not even the Angels of the heavens, but only the Father.
verses.textLa: De die autem illa, et hora nemo scit, neque Angeli cælorum, nisi solus Pater.

verses.textEn: And just as in the days of Noah, so also will be the advent of the Son of man.
verses.textLa: Sicut autem in diebus Noe, ita erit et adventus Filii hominis.

verses.textEn: For it will be just as it was in the days before the flood: eating and drinking, marrying and being given in marriage, even until that day when Noah entered into the ark.
verses.textLa: Sicut enim erant in diebus ante diluvium comedentes et bibentes, nubentes et nuptum tradentes, usque ad eum diem, quo intravit Noe in arcam,

verses.textEn: And they did not realize it, until the flood came and took them all away. So also will the advent of the Son of man be.
verses.textLa: et non cognoverunt donec venit diluvium, et tulit omnes: ita erit et adventus Filii hominis.

verses.textEn: Then two men will be in a field: one will be taken up, and one will be left behind.
verses.textLa: Tunc duo erunt in agro: unus assumetur, et unus relinquetur.

verses.textEn: Two women will be grinding at a millstone: one will be taken up, and one will be left behind.
verses.textLa: Duæ molentes in mola: una assumetur, et una relinquetur.
verses.notes: The Latin here does not actually have a word meaning woman, but the word ‘una’ is feminine, so the translation of ‘molentes’ (persons working at a grindstone) is feminine.

verses.textEn: Therefore, be vigilant. For you do not know at what hour your Lord will return.
verses.textLa: Vigilate ergo, quia nescitis qua hora Dominus vester venturus sit.

verses.textEn: But know this: if only the father of the family knew at what hour the thief would arrive, he would certainly keep vigil and not permit his house to be broken into.
verses.textLa: Illud autem scitote, quoniam si sciret paterfamilias qua hora fur venturus esset, vigilaret utique, et non sineret perfodi domum suam.

verses.textEn: For this reason, you also must be prepared, for you do not know at what hour the Son of man will return.
verses.textLa: Ideo et vos estote parati: quia qua nescitis hora Filius hominis venturus est.

verses.textEn: Consider this: who is a faithful and prudent servant, who has been appointed by his lord over his family, to give them their portion in due time?
verses.textLa: Quis, putas, est fidelis servus, et prudens, quem constituit dominus suus super familiam suam, ut det illis cibum in tempore?

verses.textEn: Blessed is that servant, if, when his lord has arrived, he shall find him doing so.
verses.textLa: Beatus ille servus, quem cum venerit dominus eius, invenerit sic facientem.

verses.textEn: Amen I say to you, he shall appoint him over all of his goods.
verses.textLa: Amen dico vobis, quoniam super omnia bona sua constituet eum.

verses.textEn: But if that evil servant has said in his heart, ‘My lord has been delayed in returning,’
verses.textLa: Si autem dixerit malus servus ille in corde suo: Moram fecit dominus meus venire:

verses.textEn: and so, he begins to strike his fellow servants, and he eats and drinks with the inebriated:
verses.textLa: et cœperit percutere conservos suos, manducet autem, et bibat cum ebriosis:

verses.textEn: then the lord of that servant will arrive on a day that he does not expect, and at an hour that he does not know.
verses.textLa: veniet dominus servi illius in die, qua non sperat, et hora, qua ignorat:

verses.textEn: And he shall separate him, and he shall place his portion with the hypocrites, where there shall be weeping and gnashing of teeth.”
verses.textLa: et dividet eum, partemque eius ponet cum hypocritis. Illic erit fletus, et stridor dentium.

verses.textEn: “Then the kingdom of heaven shall be like ten virgins, who, taking their lamps, went out to meet the groom and the bride.
verses.textLa: Tunc simile erit regnum cælorum decem virginibus: quæ accipientes lampades suas exierunt obviam sponso, et sponsæ.

verses.textEn: But five of them were foolish, and five were prudent.
verses.textLa: Quinque autem ex eis erant fatuæ, et quinque prudentes:

verses.textEn: For the five foolish, having brought their lamps, did not take oil with them.
verses.textLa: sed quinque fatuæ, acceptis lampadibus, non sumpserunt oleum secum:

verses.textEn: Yet truly, the prudent ones brought the oil, in their containers, with the lamps.
verses.textLa: prudentes vero acceperunt oleum in vasis suis cum lampadibus.

verses.textEn: Since the bridegroom was delayed, they all fell asleep, and they were sleeping.
verses.textLa: Moram autem faciente sponso, dormitaverunt omnes et dormierunt.

verses.textEn: But in the middle of the night, a cry went out: ‘Behold, the groom is arriving. Go out to meet him.’
verses.textLa: Media autem nocte clamor factus est: Ecce sponsus venit, exite obviam ei.

verses.textEn: Then all those virgins rose up and trimmed their lamps.
verses.textLa: Tunc surrexerunt omnes virgines illæ, et ornaverunt lampades suas.

verses.textEn: But the foolish ones said to the wise, ‘Give to us from your oil, for our lamps are being extinguished.’
verses.textLa: Fatuæ autem sapientibus dixerunt: Date nobis de oleo vestro: quia lampades nostræ extinguuntur.

verses.textEn: The prudent responded by saying, ‘Lest perhaps there may not be enough for us and for you, it would be better for you to go to the vendors and buy some for yourselves.’
verses.textLa: Responderunt prudentes, dicentes: Ne forte non sufficiat nobis, et vobis, ite potius ad vendentes, et emite vobis.

verses.textEn: But while they were going to buy it, the groom arrived. And those who were prepared entered with him to the wedding, and the door was closed.
verses.textLa: Dum autem irent emere, venit sponsus: et quæ paratæ erant, intraverunt cum eo ad nuptias, et clausa est ianua.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, at the very end, the remaining virgins also arrived, saying, ‘Lord, Lord, open to us.’
verses.textLa: Novissime vero veniunt et reliquæ virgines, dicentes: Domine, Domine, aperi nobis.

verses.textEn: But he responded by saying, ‘Amen I say to you, I do not know you.’
verses.textLa: At ille respondens, ait: Amen dico vobis, nescio vos.

verses.textEn: And so you must be vigilant, because you do not know the day or the hour.
verses.textLa: Vigilate itaque, quia nescitis diem, neque horam.

verses.textEn: For it is like a man setting out on a long journey, who called his servants and delivered to them his goods.
verses.textLa: Sicut enim homo peregre proficiscens, vocavit servos suos, et tradidit illis bona sua.

verses.textEn: And to one he gave five talents, and to another two, yet to another he gave one, to each according to his own ability. And promptly, he set out.
verses.textLa: Et uni dedit quinque talenta, alii autem duo, alii vero unum, unicuique secundum propriam virtutem, et profectus est statim.

verses.textEn: Then he who had received five talents went out, and he made use of these, and he gained another five.
verses.textLa: Abiit autem qui quinque talenta acceperat, et operatus est in eis, et lucratus est alia quinque.

verses.textEn: And similarly, he who had received two gained another two.
verses.textLa: Similiter et qui duo acceperat, lucratus est alia duo.

verses.textEn: But he who had received one, going out, dug into the earth, and he hid the money of his lord.
verses.textLa: Qui autem unum acceperat, abiens fodit in terram, et abscondit pecuniam domini sui.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, after a long time, the lord of those servants returned and he settled accounts with them.
verses.textLa: Post multum vero temporis venit dominus servorum illorum, et posuit rationem cum eis.

verses.textEn: And when he who had received five talents approached, he brought another five talents, saying: ‘Lord, you delivered five talents to me. Behold, I have increased it by another five.’
verses.textLa: Et accedens qui quinque talenta acceperat, obtulit alia quinque talenta, dicens: Domine, quinque talenta tradidisti mihi, ecce alia quinque superlucratus sum.

verses.textEn: His lord said to him: ‘Well done, good and faithful servant. Since you have been faithful over a few things, I will appoint you over many things. Enter into the gladness of your lord.’
verses.textLa: Ait illi dominus eius: Euge serve bone, et fidelis, quia super pauca fuisti fidelis, super multa te constituam, intra in gaudium domini tui.

verses.textEn: Then he who had received two talents also approached, and he said: ‘Lord, you delivered two talents to me. Behold, I have gained another two.’
verses.textLa: Accessit autem et qui duo talenta acceperat, et ait: Domine, duo talenta tradidisti mihi, ecce alia duo lucratus sum.

verses.textEn: His lord said to him: ‘Well done, good and faithful servant. Since you have been faithful over a few things, I will appoint you over many things. Enter into the gladness of your lord.’
verses.textLa: Ait illi dominus eius: Euge serve bone, et fidelis, quia super pauca fuisti fidelis, super multa te constituam, intra in gaudium domini tui.

verses.textEn: Then he who had received one talent, approaching, said: ‘Lord, I know that you are a hard man. You reap where you have not sown, and gather where you have not scattered.
verses.textLa: Accedens autem et qui unum talentum acceperat, ait: Domine, scio quia homo durus es, metis ubi non seminasti, et congregas ubi non sparsisti:

verses.textEn: And so, being afraid, I went out and hid your talent in the earth. Behold, you have what is yours.’
verses.textLa: et timens abii, et abscondi talentum tuum in terra: ecce habes quod tuum est.

verses.textEn: But his lord said to him in response: ‘You evil and lazy servant! You knew that I reap where I have not sown, and gather where I have not scattered.
verses.textLa: Respondens autem dominus eius, dixit ei: Serve male, et piger, sciebas quia meto ubi non semino, et congrego ubi non sparsi:

verses.textEn: Therefore, you should have deposited my money with the bankers, and then, at my arrival, at least I would have received what is mine with interest.
verses.textLa: oportuit ergo te committere pecuniam meam numulariis, et veniens ego recepissem utique quod meum est cum usura.

verses.textEn: And so, take the talent away from him and give it to the one who has ten talents.
verses.textLa: Tollite itaque ab eo talentum, et date ei, qui habet decem talenta.

verses.textEn: For to everyone who has, more shall be given, and he shall have in abundance. But from him who has not, even what he seems to have, shall be taken away.
verses.textLa: Omni enim habenti dabitur, et abundabit: ei autem, qui non habet, et quod videtur habere, auferetur ab eo.

verses.textEn: And cast that useless servant into the outer darkness, where there will be weeping and gnashing of teeth.’
verses.textLa: Et inutilem servum eiicite in tenebras exteriores: illic erit fletus, et stridor dentium.

verses.textEn: But when the Son of man will have arrived in his majesty, and all the Angels with him, then he will sit upon the seat of his majesty.
verses.textLa: Cum autem venerit Filius hominis in maiestate sua, et omnes angeli cum eo, tunc sedebit super sedem maiestatis suæ:

verses.textEn: And all the nations shall be gathered together before him. And he shall separate them from one another, just as a shepherd separates the sheep from the goats.
verses.textLa: et congregabuntur ante eum omnes gentes, et separabit eos ab invicem, sicut pastor segregat oves ab hœdis:

verses.textEn: And he shall station the sheep, indeed, on his right, but the goats on his left.
verses.textLa: et statuet oves quidem a dextris suis, hœdos autem a sinistris.

verses.textEn: Then the King shall say to those who will be on his right: ‘Come, you blessed of my Father. Possess the kingdom prepared for you from the foundation of the world.
verses.textLa: Tunc dicet Rex his, qui a dextris eius erunt: Venite benedicti Patris mei, possidete paratum vobis regnum a constitutione mundi.

verses.textEn: For I was hungry, and you gave me to eat; I was thirsty, and you gave me to drink; I was a stranger, and you took me in;
verses.textLa: Esurivi enim, et dedistis mihi manducare: sitivi, et dedistis mihi bibere: hospes eram, et collegistis me:

verses.textEn: naked, and you covered me; sick, and you visited me; I was in prison, and you came to me.’
verses.textLa: nudus, et cooperuistis me: infirmus, et visitastis me: in carcere eram, et venistis ad me.

verses.textEn: Then the just will answer him, saying: ‘Lord, when have we seen you hungry, and fed you; thirsty, and given you drink?
verses.textLa: Tunc respondebunt ei iusti, dicentes: Domine, quando te vidimus esurientem, et pavimus te: sitientem, et dedimus tibi potum?

verses.textEn: And when have we seen you a stranger, and taken you in? Or naked, and covered you?
verses.textLa: quando autem te vidimus hospitem, et collegimus te: aut nudum, et cooperuimus te?

verses.textEn: Or when did we see you sick, or in prison, and visit to you?’
verses.textLa: aut quando te vidimus infirmum: aut in carcere, et venimus ad te?

verses.textEn: And in response, the King shall say to them, ‘Amen I say to you, whenever you did this for one of these, the least of my brothers, you did it for me.’
verses.textLa: Et respondens Rex, dicet illis: Amen dico vobis, quamdiu fecistis uni ex his fratribus meis minimis, mihi fecistis.

verses.textEn: Then he shall also say, to those who will be on his left: ‘Depart from me, you accursed ones, into the eternal fire, which was prepared for the devil and his angels.
verses.textLa: Tunc dicet et his, qui a sinistris erunt: Discedite a me maledicti in ignem æternum, qui paratus est diabolo, et angelis eius.
